div.head: TO THE Virtuouly Accomplihed LADY; My LADY CHARDIN.
div.p:
THough Virtue, Honour, and all the other Accomplihments of the Mind, are not to be reflected on with the least grain of Otentation, by thoe, that the Heavens have endowed with uch eminent Quallities: Yet certainly, Madam, thoe three Illutrious Perons, repreented in this mall piece, which I Humbly offer you, would have thought themelves particularly obliged to
kind Heaven, if it had produc'd in their time, o exact a Pattern o • their own Perfections, as you are Madam; in which without the leat cruple or offence to Modety, they might have admired, with as much Jutice as Delight thoe Accomplihments, which did o viibly mark in their own Perons o great a difference from the ret of the World. Yes Madam, in you they might have lov'd the rare Qualities which were o cononant to thoe which adorn'd themelves, and which modety would not permit them to applaude in their own Perons.

Is it not therefore, with great Jutice, Madam, that I have heltered this little, but true piece of Hitory, under your afe protection. You who has o great a hare in it; you Madam,
in whom all the glittering Caracters of Perons, as great in their Perfections of Minds, as they were in their Births, do o greatly abound, you, Madam, who has o jut a dicernment in all that is excellently good, who has o nice a Judgment in the Criticim's of your own Dialect, and who is o great a Judge of our's. Finally, you, Madam, who can bet Judge of the equity with which I have proceeded, in preenting to our Englih World, the true and lively Caracters of three Perons o remarkable.

But, Madam, that you may not be inticed in your turn into ome agreable rapture, by too long a contemplation thee Excellent Perons Merits, give me leave to draw the Curtain over it, and to divert you with a
pretty piece of Turkih gallantry, in which you way behold a certain way of Courthip, as pleaant, as new to us Europeans; I am enible, Madam, it were but reaonable, I hould give you ome more particular accounts of thee two Novels, but that having been done already, ufficiently by the French Author, I hall deit therefore from giving you any further diverion, from your more erious reflections, and hall only take the Liberty of ubcribing my elf,

closer.signed: Your mot humble Servant P. Bellon.

div.head: THE ART Of making LOVE WITHOUT Speaking, Writing, or Enterveiw of the LOVERS.
div.p:
SInce I had the Honour, Sir, of entertaining you with a Dumb Language, that the Turks ue to Expres without Speaking, without Writing, and without Seeing one another, the tronget of all the Paions. You
have been exceedingly preing in obliging me to put in Writing that which I had Communicated to you in a familiar Converation. You extreamly pule me in it, and I aure you that I had beg'd your excue, had I but known the difference betwixt a particular Dicoure of two Perons in which all freedom is admitted, and from whence all Affectation is banih'd, and a tuddied Dicoure, which peradventure you will publih, and o caue it to be Criticis'd, in its Phrae, Method, Words, and in all Things ele which thoe that Write are oblig'd to oberve

I am not Ignorant of the hazard I run, I prepare my elf againt all the troubleome conequences, that my temerity will draw on me. You are oblig'd to maintain my Reputation, eeing you have firt engag'd me to atisfie your Curioity, without giving
me the leaure of reflecting on the difficulty of my enterprie. And if Love is counted the Shipwrack of Liberties and Hearts, he may well be that of my Pen alo. Be it what it will, pare me, I pray you, and expoe not this mall Peice to the public, who will not prove o kind as you are, and that will not conider, that my deign is but to Divert you in a manner of making Love, which is wholly new.

There are divers ways of expreing that Paion. The firt School in that, is that of Nature, and all thoe Leons which the Poets have given us on that Subject, would remain very ueles without the Aid and Aitance of this Univeral School Mitris.

Though the Love of the Brutes is neceary to the Conervation of their Species, Nature has added to it the eaoning of ome
preparatory Agreements, to quicken the Senes and to tir up the Natural Heat.

Man, the mot rational and enual of Animals, finds the pleaure too hort, and endeavours to prolong it, by new Inventions, he ets to work all orts of Means, to expres unto the belov'd object, what he makes us to feel, and thee Troubles which he caues in a Lovers Heart; who ometimes exprees himelf with the Voice, who employs Writing to et forth in the mot moving Manner that Ardor which conumes him, and who in defect of Voice and Writing endeavours to expres by the different Motions of his Face the Sentiments of his Heart.
Thee are the uual ways of making Love in a Country of Freedom, where Communication is eaily obtain'd, and where Perons can See, Speak, and Write to one another.

There are Nation that enjoy not thoe advantages. The greatet part of the Turks can neither Write, nor Read, neither have they the freedom of Convering with Women; yet are they not inenible. On the contrary it appears that the Eatern People are more apt to Love then any other Nation; They wholly Abandon themelves to it, there they fix their overeign good, they raie their Paion even to a Fury, and I have een ome in their Rage to Stab their Limbs with D • ggers, and then to drop burning Brimtone in the Wounds.

There is no wonder therefore that People of o Hot Tempers, when they want the ordinary means of making known their Paion, endeavour to invent extraordinary ones. Flowers, Leaves, Fruits, Aromatick Woods, Gold, Silver, all Colours, Stuffs, and in fine, almot all things that are ueful
in the Commerce of Life, enter in that of Love.

All thoe things which the Turks call Selam's, Salutes, have their ignification, and their Natural or Allegorical Valour, much like the Old way of Poetry, o that a little packet about the bignes of a Thumb does form by the everal things which it contains, a very expreive Dicoure.

This way of Expreing a Paion, will appear to you as extravagant as new. Yet it wants not its Agreements alo, and though it proceeds but from a great want of Liberty, and a defect in the mot Common of Arts, which is that of Writing and Reading, yet it is o Gallant and Ingenious, that thoe that can both Write and Read, make ue of it alo, and believe that thoe Selams, have more force and make a greater impreion on the mind, then the Characters of a Letter.
To Initiate you with delight into the Commerce of that Dumb Love, and to give you a perfect Knowledg of it. You mut be introduc'd by the Knowledg of thoe things, which Compoe that Language.

I have reduc'd them in an Alphabetical Order, to eae the finding out of thoe Names. I have Compos'd divers Letters with them, to hew you the way of their Order, and I have Inerted them in a Gallant and true Hytory, to give them more Agreement, and the more to engage you to the reading of them.

div.head: The Alphabetical Dictionary of the Dumb Language, containing the Name, Signification, Worth, and Interpretation of the Selams.

div.head: A Gallant and True HISTORY.
div.p: IT is the Cutom amongt the Turks, to pas the three Fetival Days of the Bayram, in public rejoycings. Thoe Sultanees that have their particular Palaces in the City of Contantinople and near unto it, go to the Seraglio to Viit the Sultanees, which at other times are not een. There they pas thee three days, in Sports, Feats and Dances.
Thoe amongt the Slaves, that are not Employ'd in Singing or Dancing, which makes the Chief Divertiement of the Princes, retire themelves in ome Appartment, where they Sport amongt themelves.

One day that Bournaz Atidgé, the Sultanes, Siter to Sultan Morat, was at the Seraglio with Tarhain Sultanes Validé, Mother to the Grand Segnior now Reigning. Thoe two Sultanees who were very good Friends, being deirous to entertain themelves in Private, dimis'd their Slaves.

Some of them very good friends, eparated themelves from the ret, that they might with more freedom entertain one another. They turn'd their Converation on the Love of Gulbeas white roe. She was the principal Slave of the Sultanes Validé; That Maid, at firt made ome reitance, either through Modety, or to pare her elf the Sorrow of the remembrance of a Beloved Lover. Yet he yeilded at lat to her Companions Importunities.

She told them that he had pas'd divers years without knowing what was Love, though he daily
heard her Companions Dicoure of that Paion; which produced uch trange Effects in thoe Maids mind, that he could perceive them to pas in an intant, from joy to adnes, and from Love to their Jealouy, and Deire, and that Faces would change as frequently as their Hearts were agitated with different Paions: That o Woful a Condition had caus'd her to fear uch like Engagements, and that he had hun'd them as much as he could: But at lat, aid he, Love anger'd at my reitance, forc'd me to yeild to his Power, and inpired in me ome Feelings of Tendernes for a Young Turk, Neighbour to a Jew, with whom I Boarded, to Learn the Exercies of Reading, Writing, Singing, Playing on Divers Intruments, and Dancing, in Order to be Admitted into the Seraglio.

This Turk named Iouf, Son to Mahomet Baa, was both Neighbour
and good Friend to the Jew, and he did frequently come to his Houe, to hear me Sing. He conceiv'd o trong a Paion for me, that he pas'd both Days and Nights at his Window, or in his Garden to ee me: And one day, he ventur'd to pake to me of his Love, but his Dicoures made o mall Impreion on my mind, that I had not at that time the leat Sentiment of Tendernes for him.

Sometime after that Peron who had put me to the Jew, finding me ufficiently Intructed, Preented me to the Sultanes my Mitris. Abence, which is a great Remedy againt Love, intead of alaying Ioufs Paion, erv'd but to increae it, while I liv'd, without the leat diturbance in the Seraglio, where Love had not yet diturb'd my Ret.

He did endeavour by all orts of means to learn ome News of
the Peron he lov'd; all his endeavours were fruitles, The Gates of the Womens Apartment are inacceible places. Thoe Cerberues that keep them, enraged and deperate to find themelves depriv'd of that which might render them agreeable to o many Beauties which they have under their Conduct, become Jealous, and have more Eyes then Argus to examine all their Actions.

So many difficulties had a mot repuls'd Iouf, who had conumated three years in fruitles Attempts. He did Abandon himelf to Grief and complaining, when one of his Friends who har'd in his Sorrow, inform'd him that a Jewih Woman Merchant, named Boullater, had free Acces in the Seraglio, where he old a great many J • wels to the Sultanees.

Iouf who had Wit, and Means, made good ue of his Friends Advice, and built great Hopes on it, being
perwaded that Money overcomes all difficulties, and that Liberality moves the mot obdurate Hearts. He reolv'd to confide his Love to this Jewih Woman, and to engage her in his Concerns.
The Enterprie was not very difficult, coniderable Preents, and Promies of Reiterating them upon a favourable Succes, did engage the Jewih Woman to erve Iouf in his Amours.

He put into her hands a Pair of Pendants of Emeralds cut in the hape of Pairs, a pair of Diamond Bracelets, and the Buckles of a Girdle et with Rubies, in Enamel'd Gold. He Accompanyed this Preent with a Billet, and a Seliman, put up in a Watch Cae of Enamel'd Gold, et with Diamonds. He Conjur'd his Meenger to ue all her Indutry to perwade and convince me of the exces of his Love, and to repreent to me the Diorders which
that Paion had made in his Heart, the deplorable Condition in which it had reduc'd him, that I had been almot three years in the Seraglio, and could not all that while learn any News of me, that he was ready to Dye if all that he had uffer'd for me was not capable to molifie me, and to inpire ome kindnes for him in my Breat.

The Jewih Woman, who was very Dextrous and Prudent, coming to the Seraglio as he us'd to do, took her time when the Sultanes was not viible, and eeking of an opportunity of peaking to me conveniently, requeted that I hould give her leave to ret her elf a while in my Apartment, which I could not in Civility refue her, I being he which this Jewih Merchant bet knew, by reaon of my Place of Treaurer to the Sultanes, to which I had been advanc'd, in a hort time,
through the Sultanees ingular Bounty.

Women are naturally Curious, I inform'd my elf of the quality of her Jewels. She heightned their Beauties and Perfections, pulling out of her Boom a box in which thoe things were put up, he hew'd them me.
The fires and parklings of thoe precious Stones, on which I mot earnetly gaz'd, with an envious Eye, invited me to put them on me for a while.

The Jewih Woman, who perceiv'd that I was coming to the Lure, and that this dres pleas'd me, did invite me with her praies to frequently Conult a mall Looking-glas which I had found by chance, which made me oberve an extraordinary rednes on my Face, caus'd by a Vexation, that Fortune had not favour'd me, with uch a like Treaure.

Boulluter who eaily perceiv'd what pas'd in my Heart, knowing that every moment was precious, thought it high time to Play her Part, and to dicover to me Ioufs Paion in giving me his Letter and Preent.

Charming Gulbeas, aid he, I mut confes to you how much I am urpris'd that the Sultan is not yet taken with your Beauty, and with o many Graces which I oberve in your Face; there is nothing in you but what is capable to Produce Love, and if that Emperor had once een you in this Dres, the Sultanes would conceive ome Jealouie thereon, and I eaily believe what has been told me of the Paion of a Young Turk whoe Name is Iouf.

Though I had not heard him mention'd ince I had been Admitted into the Seraglio, no more then of the Jew with whom I had
liv'd, that Name made me change Colour, for that young Man's Paion was not unknown to me, eeing he had entertain'd me with it before. I did all I could to diguie my Surprial, and to Conceal the Motions of my Soul, but that Poion that had thrown it elf there and o long fomented, without perceiving it, dicover'd it elf againt my will by a Sigh drawn from the bottom of my Heart, which I could not for my Life retain.

Boullater made o good ue of the diorder in which he perceiv'd me to be, and made me o lively a draft of Ioufs Paion, and Merit, that laying aide her indifferency in that buines, he made an end of engaging me, in preenting me with the Box of Diamonds. I thought at firt that it had been a Watch: My Curioity invited me to open it, but in lieu of a Watch Movement I found in it a Billet.
Honour made me immediately hut it up again, and return it to the Woman. I Counterfeited the Angry Body, yet would I gladly have been inform'd of the Contents of that Billet, not doubting but that it was Iouf's, Declaration of Love, who began to pleae me. The Jewih Woman who had too much of Experience not to dicern my feigning, did Pres me to take the Box, I did it proteting it was meerly in Complaiance, and to free me from her Importunities.
I pulling out the Billet found under it a little Packet which inclos'd a Selam, but becaue I can Read well, I intantly open'd the Billet, which was expres'd in thee Terms.

To See and to Love you Divine Gulbeas have been to me the ame thing. The Gods who have made you o Fair, ought to have made you
more enible alo, or not have poes'd we with o much Love, and o little of hopes. My Paion is as Ancient as the knowledge which I have had of your Merit, and Time which Conumes all things has erv'd but to increae it. There are pas'd divers years ince I am no more my elf, and that I live but for you. I pas both days and nights in that part of the Garden, where I did hear you Sing, and Play on your Intruments, and from whence I did ometimes pake to you. That place once the Confident of my Delights, is now the ame of my Sorrow, and will oon be that of my Death, if you caue not my Detiny to alter, not being any longer capable of Life without eeing you. I am not Ignorant of the difficulty of the Attempt; but mot Incomparable Beauty, if you will afford me but a little pitty, who Languihes for you, and the happines of cating my elf down at your Feet, leave all the ret to Prudent
Boullaters Cares, he will know how to manage my Blis and your Reputation.

The Reading of this Billet gave me the Curioity of unfolding the Selam. It was Compos'd of a grain of Grape, a little Race of Ginger, a mall piece of Cole, and Alum, lapp'd up in white and yellow Silk, which ignified as follows.

p.hi: I wih, My Eyes, that you were perfectly inform'd of that Love which I feel for you. It deprives me of my elf, and if you take not pitty of the Condition I am in, I hall Dye while you will enjoy an happy Life: Honour me with an Anwer, and put an end to my ufferings.

div.p:
Though I feign'd not to be well pleas'd at this Declaration which I thought omething too free, my Heart was very well atisfied with
Ioufs Contancy. It poke to me in his hehalf, and there needed not any great effects to perwade me of his Love, and to inpire in me ome tendernes towards him.

The Jewih Woman, who tudied my Countenance, perceiving the Effects of the Letter, and of the Selam, did preently offer me the Jewels with which I was already adorn'd. My reaon, which was not yet wholly prepoes'd, made me to refue them, and to Repreent to her the wrong which it might do to my Reputation, hould the Sultanes dicover it, and that I could not accept of a preent that would be the caue of my Ruine. At the ame time I undid thoe Jewels which I return'd her with the Box, retaining nothing but the Letter and the Selam.

Boullater who a long Practice had render'd expert, was of Opinion that ometimes a too great
earnetnes, does impede the ucces which is mot deir'd, did endeavour to convince me by a means to which I could make no reitance.

She told me that my Beauty being Aited with o powerful an Addition, I might pleae the Grand Segnior, and peradventure be made Sultanes. The Ambition of Reigning, at leat in an Emperors Heart, carried it above my Reaon, and made me conent to receive the Preent.

She would gladly have had me as ready to have receiv'd Iouf in my Appartment: My Heart did not reject the propoition, had not my reaon render'd me inexorable. Finally after long intances and reiterated intreaties, I conented to ee him in the Garden.

Boullater could have wih'd (to acquit her elf handomly of her Commiion) that I had given her
an Anwer; Honour and Reaon oppos'd it, but Love did engage me to let him know by a Selam, that his Paion was not unpleaing to me, it was lapp'd up in an Handkercheif of Silk Embroider'd with Gold, wrought with my own Hand, after which the Woman retir'd, pretending before my Companions, who had urpris'd us in the Converation, that he left thoe Jewels with me, that I might hew them to the Sultanes.
Iouf impatient to learn the ucces of his enterprie expected his Agents return, who made him an exact Relation of all that had pas'd, and gave him that Handkercheif which I had ent him.

The Joy which he reented at the receit of this aurance of the acceptance of his Paion, did Tranport him in uch manner, that without examining what it contain'd, he kis'd it a thouand times, and water'd it with his
Tears, with the mot tender Expreions, that Love could inpire.

Boullater who would not interrupt him during the height of his Tranport, when he was come to himelf again a little, made him to take Notice of the Selam. It was Iabella Silk, a Sprig of Jeemy, a little bit of Spunge, ome Time, and ome Mirtle.

I cannot expres to you the exces of the Joy which Iouf conceiv'd at it, it was o great that he was truck Speechles, and that Rapture had lated longer, if Boullaster, as Curious, as he was Contented, had not pres'd him to give her the Expoition of it. I accept your Vows, aid the Selam, be perwaded of my Constancy, provided you be o I pray Heaven to betow you on me, and that our Souls may be ineparably joyn'd together.

Is it poible mot Amiable Gulbeas, aid Iouf, that my Paion,
is agreeable to, you is it not to deecive me, and to Laugh at my Grief, that thus you eek to engage me further, and kiing the Handkercheif, he aid, dear Pledge of the fidelity of he who I adore, will you be it alo of the incerity of her Heart. Then Addreing himelf to the Selam, and you Dumb Mouth, will you aure me the duration of her new Born Love?
He had aid more; but all Moments were Precious to prepare himelf for this Enterview.

The difficulty of this enterprie did cat him in a new Sorrow, and plung'd him in a Melancholy more profound then the former. He was in a dipair of finding in the Seraglio, a Friend o faithful as to be truted with his Amours, and his Impatiency did increae, till as he grew nearer the o deired time.

After he had much Tormented himelf on the means of bringing about his deign, he remembred that there was a Mater Gardner nam'd, Outa Mehemet, who was greatly oblig'd to his Father, and that that conideration, might engage him to do him Service, he reolv'd to find him out.

Outa Mehemet, who had preerv'd for Iouf a natural Inclination, receiv'd him with Demontrations of a perfect Friendhip, and great protetations of acknowledgments of the good Offices which he had receiv'd from the Baa, his Father.

Though Iouf was atisfied of Mehemets fidelity, and that he doubted not but that though he hould not grant him the favour which he was about to ask of him, that he would however keep his ecret, he however exacted from him an Oath, on the Head of the Prophet, never to reveal that which
he would intrut him with, which he eaily obtain'd from Mehemet.

Iouf dicovered his Paion to his Friend in uch enible Terms, and o preing, that though he had not had any mind to erve him, it was no longer in his power to refue him. I Love, mot faithful Mehemet, but what erves my Love, when that I cannot pake to the Object of my Vows. I Love a Fair One, Prioner in this Place, the inward part of the Seraglio which is Guardian of this Treaure, is almot Penetrable, or at leat the Acces is o difficult, that it cannot be attempted without a great hazard; Yet that is not the thing which detains Me, my Paion which is beyond all limits would make me to undertake all things, if that he whom I Love would conent to it. I have only obtain'd to ee her from a little Garden of Flowers which is jut under the Sultanee's Appartment. You,
My Dear Mehemet, mut facilitate the entry of it to me, on you depends the ucces of this Enterprie; I have Built on your Friendhip; and if ever you have lov'd, you will judge of the Importancy of the Service, and the greatnes of the Obligation, that I hall be indebted to you for it.

That Declaration had made too great an Impreion on this Old Mans Mind, the remembrance of thoe Diorders which a like Paion had formerly Caus'd in his Breat, did make him condecend with eae to Ioufs requet, without conidering the danger unto which he expos'd himelf, hould the intreague be dicover'd. He promied to introduce him under a Gardiners habit, and that he had no more to do, but to oberve my appointed time.

Iouf did preently dipatch Boullater to the Seraglio, he gave her no Letter, his Joy was too
great to permit him to write. He only gave her a mall Selam, compos'd of a grain of Pomegranate a little piece of nctious Wood, lapp'd in white Silk, a Gray-pea, a little piece of Suggar Cane, and the kernel of an Hazel Nut, all which did pake thus.

p.hi: The fire which your love has kindled in my Hearty, has reduc'd me to uch a Condition, that if you take not pitty of me and that if like the Sun, you enlighten not my mind, I hall oon looe that with my life.

div.p:
Though I was highly poes'd with Love, I had till ome reaon left me, I wa • kept in with fear, I dreaded leat the intreague hould be dicover'd, and that the Sultanes hould caue me to be everely Punih'd: Thus I would, yet would not, yet at lat I was forc'd to yeild to the Syrenes Enchantments. I promis'd her that the next day at nine I would render my elf in alow room which
anwer'd on the Garden, and which was parted from it but by a Lattice Window, of which I hould open a mall wicket, which would be the ign of my coming, that that was the mot favourable time, that the Sultanes did uually ret, and her Women alo, after breakfats; and that all the Eunuchs were on the outide of the Gate, to prevent all noie.

Iouf had like to have dyed, at the receit of this news, which did caue him ome retlenes, through the apprehenions that his ill Fortune might make him micarry in this attempt. He pas'd the whole night with terrible apprehenions, mixt of fear and hope.

He render'd himelf at the Seraglio, at the appointed hour. Mehemet caus'd him to change his rich habit for a Gardiners dres, made of a coure red Serge, with a cap a Foot long, of the ame
Stuff. He put a Spade in his hand, and conducted him to the Garden ordering him to dig a border jut under the Windows of that Appartment; at every troke the new Gardner would lift up his Eyes, to oberve whither the wicket did open; but unluckily, the Sultanes being fallen aleep a little latter then uually, the Gardner had leaure to dig almot all the border, before I could come to the Rendevouz.

He was very impatient, as I was inform'd, he would ome time hear your great flyes, which eeking for paage would trike againt the Lattice, which made him fancy that I was looking and laughing at his lavery.

When I came near the Window, and that through the Lattice, I perceiv'd Iouf with the Spade in his hand, I no longer doubted of the trength of his love, and though it was a little uneay to
me to ee a Peron of his Quality digging of the ground, to enjoy one moment the atisfaction of eeing me, it gave me a ecret joy, and without reflecting on what my abence might make him to uffer, I took a great delight in conidering of him without hewing my elf. But he having work'd a coniderable time, and that o harh an exercie to o tender a Body, did oblige him, to ret often on his Spade, and to cat up his Eyes from time to time on the place where I was to appear, I open'd the wicket, and aw Ioufs Pain to redouble, the Spade fell out of his hands, he remain'd without motion, like a tatue, but by good Fortune he was not perceiv'd, Mehemet who had foreen the conequences of this firt ight, had et the Gardners at ome ditance, who were to have work'd in the ame place.

There is no greater trouble,
then to be in preence of that one loves, and not in power to declare ones grief. That which Iouf did uffer by being depriv'd of peaking to me becaue of the nearnes of the Sultanes's appartment, was as troubleom to me as to himelf, and notwithtanding all the reervednes which I pretended to, I uffered no les then he did. By good Fortune the Dumb Language, which is very much us'd in this Court, and that we perfectly undertood, did o well upply the defects of our Voices, that we eparated well atisfied with one another. The Eyes, the motions of the face, the igns of the Fingers, and the getures of the Body, did all peak more then the mot fluent tongue could have utter'd, which is frequently Dumb in uch occaions, and ays nothing at all for having too much to ay. We did o pleae our elves in this converation, that it
had continu'd longer, if I had not heard ome treading in the Sultanes's appartment, which oblig'd me to make igns to Iouf to retire; and o I hut the wicket.

During all our intreagues, Boullater, who was now the confident of our mutual amours, made divere Journeys to the Seraglio. I took no les delight at the news of my lovely Iouf, then he did of his dear Gulbeas. He was very rich, and did promie me to ue all his Endeavours, and to employ all his Friends, to get me out of the Seraglio, and to marry me. This had not doubtles deceiv'd my hopes, if a precipitated Death caus'd by the Plague had not depriv'd me of my only Joy.

Sobbs and ighs, mix'd with Tears, interrupted Gulbea's relation, and the trength of her grief having dienabled her from finihing, he intreated one of her Companions, to whom he
had dicovered her ecret, to go on with the recital of a Death, which had cot her o many Tears. Patma, o was that good Friend call'd, continu'd G • lbea's dicoure. The Jewih Woman, did come twice or thrice a week to the Seraglio, though he ould but few things there; but he was ufficiently recompens'd by thoe lovers, whoe preents did in a hort time make her very rich.

Their Paions grew beyond all limits, Iouf, who was impatient at his Incomparable Mitris's abence, would attempt a econd enterview, in which he might freely, with a loud Voice and not by Dumb igns expres the exces of his love. He communicated his deign to his confident, reiterating large promies if he had good ucces. She being won by the gains, did engage to omit nothing that might tend to his atisfaction.

She came to the Seraglio, gave Gulbeas a Selam put up in an Agath veel. It is to be confes'd aid Patmas, that if love harpens Wit, it borders on folly alo, Iouf would engage his Mitris with a rich preent. This Veel was Garnih'd with circles of Gold tudded with Diamonds, and he endeavour'd to convince her of her paion, by a Selam, compos'd of his Hairs, of Roe colour Silk, of Aloes Wood, of Antimony, of Nutmeg, a Sprig of Broom, a grain of Grape, a mall peice of Cloth, and of Cole, all which put together did ay.

p.hi:
Precious Crown of all my wihes, Nightingal whoe Voice is only capable to Charm the orrow of my Soul, true remedy of the Evils which I endure, conider the Tears which proceed from my Eyes, while that perhaps you are Laughing at my grief take pity on me, and behold the condition in which you have brought
me. I am ready to dye, if you honour me not with your writing, and if you give me not a poitive Anwer.

div.p:
This Selam, and the relation which Boullater made to Gulbeas, of the mierable condition that Iouf was in, whom he repreented to her, languihing, and dying, did o move her, being put on with paion and love, that he conented to a econd enterview, the p •• ce and manner, only, did trouble her, and he caus'd him ome by a little Selam, of a Gold Wyer, of a grain of Grape, of a grain of Millet, of a bit of white thred, and of a grain of Wheat, all which aid. Come my Eyes I am enible of your griefs, my Heart is yours, be perwaded of my Constancy. Gulbeas would not conent to Iouf's diguie for his admittance into an appartment which was joyning that of the Sultanes; It was
a lippery tep, no les then honour and life were at take. All thoe coniderations were powerful enough to brake off that deign, if love who was the tronget had not overpois'd them. Gulbeas let her elf be won by Boullater's perwaion, and gave her leave to bring Iouf diguis'd like a Maiden.

Three days were employ'd in getting things ready, the rather becaue that too frequent viits might have been upected. They were o many Ages to the Amorous Iouf, for whom neat and proper Cloths were getting ready that his dres anwering to the Beauty of his Face, where no Hair had yet appear'd the Guards might be with more eae impos'd upon.

The 4th. day Boullater, and her pretended Daughter whom we will call Gevaher, which in the Turkih Language ignifies, Precious-Stone, came to the
Seraglio. This She-Merchant who was well known, having told that who accompany'd her was her Daughter, deceiv'd the Black Eunuchs, who let them both enter.

Here Patma made a paue, and beginning again with a languihing accent, he aid, Iouf, what dot thou doe? you come to ee Gulbeas you eek in her Eyes for a remedy to your Evils, you are going to find the end of them but after a very extraordinary manner, your preence hall cure her of the Plague which overcomes her, and by a trange counter-blow, you will take in, in approaching her, a Poyon, that hall kill you.

Of truth, continued he, The Jewih Woman did introduce the fair Gevaher, into the dying Gulbea's Chamber. Judge of the trouble that Iouf found himelf in, and if the urprial of uch an unexpected accident were not capable of breaking all
the meaures of this diguie.

There little wanted but that he dicover'd himelf, but Gulbeas who till preerv'd a ound Judgment with the rigour of her dieae, which was at the third day, did intreat her companions, to leave her one moment alone with this Jewih Woman, to ettle ome accounts which they had together.

When that Iouf found himelf alone near Gulbeas, he gave full cope to his grief, and forgeting the place he was in, he tore of his vail, and cleav'd to the Beds Head of the ick Peron, who he bathed with his Tears not being able to peak one word. Gulbeas on her ide did receive uch preing trokes of love, with the anguih of her dieae, that it cauing a great revolution in her Body, a Chriis was produc'd, which aved her life, and gave Iouf his death who could not be perwaded to quit the Boulter, where he took in
the team of a Malignant weat, which peirc'd him to the very Heart, and caus'd him to fall in a fainting Fit.

p.U: trangly confus'd at the wooning of her pretended Daughter, and much more at the conequences that the unraveling of this intreague might produce in cae that the illnes increaing, he had been oblig'd to be put into a bed, call'd me to ait her.

div.p: When I came in, the feigned Gevaher began to breath and to igh, turning her Eyes towards Gulbeas, whoe name he poke with uch a tender and amourous accent, that I wonder how I perceiv'd it not, I reflected not on it, and did attribute it to an ancient acquaintance, that which was a pure effect of love.

It pas'd not o with Boullater, he was o urpris'd that all her enes fled from her, and her face growing pale he fell in a woon, o that
I was left alone very buy, and concern'd. I brought the Daughter near to Gulbeas's Bed, and run to the Mother who was not long fainted, when both were recover'd of their woon, I went to prepare omething for them to take.

The Amorous Iouf made ue of that moment to ay ome few things to his Mitris, which he pronounc'd with a Languihing Voice. Death, which perues me, aid he, is a les trouble to me, adorable Gulbeas, then the pain which I feel for what you endure. I hould run to it with Pleaure, if I thought it would eae you, be perwaded of it, and that I had rather dye, then abandon you, If I did not expoe you, by my tay here to a danger greater then your Dieae. I retire, but I retire to dye, not being able to reist o much orrow. Gulbeas overcome with the trength of her dieae, peirc'd to the quick at Ioufs illnes, and weakned with
the violence of her Criis, could not anwer thoe tender aurances but with Tears, which made her faint away. Here it was that Poor Iouf had need of his whole tock of reaon, to reit o much Grief, and yet Act nothing that might betray the ecret, he was forc'd to ret contented with ighs, which were attributed to his late fainting.
Gulbeas was long in that condition, and beginning to Breath again, Boullater who fear'd ome new accident, endeavour'd all he could to bring back Iouf, from his afflicted Mitris.

He could not reolve on uch a ad eparation, which he foreaw would be eternal; He would fain have expir'd near what he lov'd, yet he was forc'd to obey his Mitris's orders, who made igns to him, not being able to pake, and gave him her hand, which he kis'd, proteting that he would not out live her.

All thoe accidents which had accompanyed o ad an enterview, was not ufficient to overcome our unfortunate Lovers. It happen'd that paing by one of the doors of the Seraglio where there tands Baltadges, which are certain varlets from without, that one of them ditruting the feigned Gevahers going, which was become careles through her grief and pain; fancy'd it a diguie, and top'd Iouf by the arm; Boullater, whoe Wit was always at hand, without peaking to the Baltadgj, for fear of bringing more to them, drawing near, dropt into his hand a ring which he pull'd of her own Finger, and preing his hand he thereby oblig'd him to give liberty to this poor Lover to get out, who thought much les on the preent accident then on Gulbea's troubles.

So oon as Iouf was return'd to his Palace, he went to his Bed,
his Feaver increas'd, and finding himelf pres'd with that dieae which kill'd him, he would employ that little time he had to live, in taking leave of his dear Mitris, and to give her his lat farewell.

I dye for you, Incomparable Gulbeas, and Death is the more pleaing to me, becaue I hope that its Caue which was your Criis, will be that of the prolongation of your days. I hould dye without trouble, had I the certain news of it. The dieae prees upon me, and I employ that little time which is left me, in giving you tetimonies of a love which I hall carry to my grave: happy if that lat moment can better convince you then divers Years of Sighs and Tears have done. Adieu, all lovely, live and remember that the ame love which retores you to Life is the Caue of my Death.

No ooner had he ended his
Letter, but he immediately ent it with the Ring on his Finger, in which his Mitris's name and his were Ingraven on a very clear Ruby, to Boullater, and was preently eis'd with a diturbance in his head, and a redoubling of his Feaver, which depriv'd him of his Senes and Speech, which never return'd again but with the lat igh, which he vented, in pronouncing the lovely name of his Mitris.

Gulbeas, whoe Criis had put out of all Danger, the weat having Diipated the Tumors of the Plague, was more Ditemper'd in the Mind then the Body, Iouf's ilence, and Boullater's tay from giving her an Account of all that had pas'd, ince their parting, did trangly Perplex her, and giving her ad Warnings of what was coming, he felt mot mortal diquiets, he would Weep all
Day, and the Night was pas'd in Watchings, or in Terrible Viions, which foretold her nothing but thoe Dangers which he fear'd. The ame night that Iouf expir'd, he thought that a Woman of a Prodigious height, as Lean as a Skelleton, and of a frightful Deformity, her Hairs pread abroad approaching her with the Face of a Fury, a great Knif in her Hand, was opening of her ide, and pulling out her Heart. All thoe Nocturnal Viions, Augmented her Sorrows. She had made Choice of me for her Confident ever ince Iouf's adventure, I did endeavour to Divert her, and turn her off of all thoe Melancholy Thoughts, nothing could Adminiter Comfort to her; But it was much wors, when Boullater came to the Seraglio, ome days after Isoufs Death, to acquit her elf of the lat Commiion, which he had given her.

So oon as he did ee her, he earnetly Inform'd her elf of Iouf's welfare; but the Jewih Woman's ilence, who could not diemble, nor keep in her Tears, gave her eaily to undertand that truth which he fear'd to learn, Ah! Cry'd he, Iouf is no longer in being! and preently fell in my Arms in a Swoon.

When he was come to her elf again, Iouf's Letter and Ring which Boullater put into her Hands, not being able to peak one word, did Confirm that Sorrowful News, She Divers times kis'd thoe dear Pledges of Iouf's eternal Contancy, Water'd them with her Tears, and did hang the Ring at her Neck, as a Mark that he Devouted her elf to her Lover's Ghot; and having remain'd ometime without Speech, her Face from Pale as it was, became Red, and as if he were become Furious.
Fatal Detiny, cry'd he, thou Renders me my Life in killing what I Love, and thou ellet me very dear, that which I can no longer Love, eeing that he, with whom I deign'd to hare it, is no more. Why didt thou not kill me, or why didt thou Conduct him here, that I might be further oblig'd to him of my Life? after o many Services o ill rewarded, I will no longer Live after uch an Accident; Alas! what will Life ignifie to me, after that he, who Animated me is Dead. No Iouf, I deign'd not to Live but for you, and I hould be unworthy of your Love hould I have any other thoughts. That Death which was to have taken me off, has not pared me, in taking of you. It has doubly lain me in depriving me of what I Love, and permitting me to Linger out a Mierable Life, which hall be but a Continual Death. You Live Iouf, and your most happy hade, enjoys at preent the Pleaures of the Eliicumfields,
and I hall never ceae Dying till I am reunited to you. Then Addreing her elf to the Ring. This Ring, continu'd he, hall be henceforth the Faithful witnes of my Love, and eeing it could not nite our Bodies during our Lives, it hall be the indio lubbiletye of our Wills, and the Mark with which I will appear before you, I will continually wear it in my Boom, and it hall Accompany me in my Grave, eeing you could not have any other thought, when you ent it me at your Death, than that of uniting me more trictly to you in the other World.

She had continu'd, and gone on further with her Complaints, if the preence of our Companions, had not interrupted their Coure and oblig'd Boullater to retreat. The Grief for his Death brought her into a Lingering Feaver, which has caus'd that Languihing Condition you ee her in,
and of which there is no likelihood he will ever be Cured, the caue of her illnes being too dear to her.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p:
TO give an advantageous Character of this Novel, there needed but to name the Peron that Compos'd it. The great Succes which all the Ingenious Works which, She has produc'd, have had, would be ufficient to put an Eteem on this, and none can doubt of its worth after the great Approbations that have been given to all the rest. But in this Particular I am not Permitted to Satisfie the Curioity of the Publick. Her Will oppoes it elf unto that Glory that She might jutly pretend from it, and She does ret atisfied with the bare Secret Delight which She receives, in that which She Pro •… ares to the Ingenious. Yet I believe not that all Her Cautiounes can Conceal Her from the knowing. The Nicety
of the Sentiments, the Towr of the Conceptions, the clear and eaie Stile, all does here Conpire to Her Dicovery. The Virtue of three as Illutrious as Unfortunate Perons, which Vye with one another who hall mot overcome themelves in Greatnes of Souls, Produces in the Heart uch Motions of Tendernes and of Pitty as do extreamly Delight. The Character of that Nation, which makes the Subject of this Novel, appears o Natural that it will not be Difficult to Believe the Truth of the Principal Events. Thoe that have Read the Portugal Hytory, will agree to it, and I need not make any stay here to Prove it. I hall only ay, that if an Ingenious Fiction, has Power to exite and stir up our Paions, a Truth o well Penn'd, as this is, will not fail of moving the leat enible Perons, and to draw uch Tears from them, as they would gladly let fall.

div.head: THE Fatal Beauty OF AGNES de CASTRO.
div.p: THough Love promies nothing but Pleaures, the Effects of it are ometimes ad. A Tender heartednes is not ufficient to attain to a Perfect Happines; and that Capricious Fortune which croes all things, has but very little regard to Paionate Hearts, when She is in the Humour of producing trange Adventures.
Divers Examples of the pas'd Ages prove the Certainty of this Maxim; But the Reign of Don, Alfone, the 4th. of that Name King of Portugal does furnih us with one the mot Extraordinary.

He was the Son of that Don Denis, whoe Enterpries did o well ucceed, that it was aid of
him, he did all that he would, and of Iabella of Aragon a Princes of an Eminent Virtue. After he had inherited a Flourihing and quiet Etate he Endeavoured to Maintain in it both Plenty and Peace, by all means imaginable.

To that end he fix'd the Marriage of his Son Don Pedre, who was but eight years old, with Blanch Daughter to Don Pedre, King of Catile, who the Young Prince did Marry at ixteeen. She brought along with her at Coimbria divers Infirmities, and but a few Agreements. Don Pedre who had a tock of Mildnes and of Bounty, notwithtanding all thoe inconveniencies, did live in good intelligence with her; But at lat thoe inconveniences being degenerated into a Paralitic Ditemper, and Blanch herelf being deirous of a retreat the Pope did annul the Marriage. The Princes did confine in Solitude all her Languihments and the Prince for whom
other Nuptials had been prepar'd, did marry Contantia Manuel, Daughter to Don John Manuel, Prince of the Blood of Catile, and famous for that reitance, which he made to hi • King.

Contantia had been promied to the King of Catile; but he breaking his Word, he was given to a young Prince, who was once to reign over a coniderable number of fair Provinces. He was but in his twenty fifth year, and the hanomet Man of all Spain: with the mot advantageous Qualities of the Body, he poet thoe of the Soul, and in all things, he did prove himelf worthy of that Crown, which was appointed for him.

The Princes Contantia was Beautiful, Spirituous, and generous as much as any Woman in the World, her Merit ought to have Captivated Don Pedre, and certainly he had for her an Eteem mix'd with repect; which might have pas'd for Love with the les
Penetrating Perons. Mean time his more real Flames were reerv'd for another Beauty.

Contantia, brought forth a Son in the firt Year of her Marriage; who was Named Don Louis, and who carce had the time to dicern the light; The los of him did caue her to feel many Sorrows; but that cold indifferency which he oberv'd in thoe Cares which her Husband did betow on her, was much more enible to her. It had not been difficult for her to give herelf wholly to her Duty, and to ingularly cleave to his tender Affections, but that powerful Interet which bound her o trictly unto the Prince of Portugal, did open her Eyes on his actions, where he could not find any thing that was Natural, and that could atisfiy her Nicety.

At firt he thought he had deceived herelf; but time having confirm'd what he fear'd, he did ecretly igh for it, and had o much
Conideration for the Prince as to give him but ome obliging marks of her Sorrow, which he could not Conceal from Agnes de Catro, who lived with her, and the Princes Affection did ditinguih her from all the other Women.

This Maiden o dear to the Princes, did well deerve that preference which he gave her. She was exceively Beautiful, wie, dicreet, Spirituous, and more Affectionate for Contantia then he was for her own Interet, having left her Family, whoe name was Illutrious, and that did hold a very Coniderable rank, to give herelf wholly to the Princes, and to follow her into Portugal. It was in her boom that he poured forth her firt Sorrow, and the Charming Agnes omitted nothing that could Adminiter Comfort to her.

Contantia was not the only Peron which Complained of Don
Pedre, before the Divorce of Blanch, he had expre'd ome Tendernes towards Elvira Goncales, Siter to Don Alvar Goncales, Favorite to the King of Portugal; and that Amuement of the Princes younget Years, having made a real Impreion on Elvira, whoe Ambition had been flatter'd by Blanche's Infirmities, he had een Contantia poes her place, with a ecret Rage, and to be Mitres of Sufficiency of Charms to take from her all to the lat hopes.

Her Jealouy left her not long idle; he examin'd all the Prince's Actions, and without difficulty did unravel the Caue of that indifferency, which he had for his Spoue: But that did not bring him back to her, and it was with great preumption, that he mitruted ome new Paion in him, which he promied to her elf to thwart o oon a • he hould find it out. She had a mind that was very fit for bold Enterpries, and her Brothers Credit did
raie uch a pride in her, that all the Princes indifferency was not capable to humble.

He did languih, and none could gues at the Caue, he had no longer any relih for public Sports, ordinary converations were uneay, and olitude only had ome power over him; this change urpris'd every body, Don Alfono, who lov'd his Son, deign'd to dicoure him about it; but the Prince gave no other Anwer, than, that it was an effect of his Temper.

All this while, time did pas, and the Princes was deliver'd of a econd Son, who liv'd and was nam'd Ferdinando. Don Pedre did force himelf a little to ta ••… a hare in the public Joy. It was believ'd that the humour was going to alter; but that glimpe of a Calm lated not long, and he oon did relape into his deep Melancholly.

The plotting Elvira was inceantly agitated, in eeking after the Knowledg of his Secret. Chance
labour'd for her in it. One day, that he was walking of her fury in the Palace's Gardens, he found the Prince of Portugal aleep in an obcure Grotto. Her Fury could not hold againt that Object. She cat her Eyes on him, and perceiv'd that in pight of leep ome Tears did teal from his Eyes. That hare which he till had in her heart, had no hard task to often it; but he heard him igh, and afterwards to expres thee ill articulated Words: Yes, divine Agnes, I will dye before I dicover it, and Contantia hall have no Caue to reproach you any thing. Elvira was eis'd with horror at that dicoure, which preently repreented to her Imagination Agnes de Catro with all her charms, and not doubting but that it was he who poet Don Pedre's heart, he felt more hatred againt that Rival, than he had of Tendernes for him. The Grotto was no it place to make Reflections in, and to form
deigns. Perhaps that her firt tranport had caus'd her to have awakned the Prince, had he not perceiv'd under his hand a Paper, which he eis'd, and that he might not be urpris'd reading of it, he went forth with as much diligence as emotion.
When he was got to her Apartment, he open'd the Paper trembling, and in it found thee Veres writ with Don Pedre's own hand, which it is likely he had newly compos'd.

q.l: Deit, Torment no more my Heart,
Honour, and Sacred Rights, chief conerns of my Glory
Love whipers me another tory.
And I yeild to his Conquering Art.
Ye eeming over lating ties,
Conspell'd engagements, Oaths Love never made,
You mut all, at his feet be laid
As a Mot humble Sacrifice.
Dear Princes, you, to whom my Faith is due,
Pardon my over-ruling Fate,
'Tis confes'd, I deerve your hate.
'Las! tis my Star renders me fale to you.

div.p: Elvira knew well Don Pedre's Writing, and was not Ignorant that he made Veres, and oberving the ad part that Hymen Acted in thoe which was fallen into her hands, She Scrupled not to produce them to the Princes: That he might not be upected, She appeared not in the leat; but it being not ufficient to caue Contantia to oberve how little her Husband Lov'd her, and that it was neceary alo, to inform her, that he was become Agnes de Castros, Slave, Elvira caus'd thee few Words, in an Unknown Hand, to be Writ under the Princes Veres, where there was a ufficient pace.

q.l: Sleep betray'd this unlucky Lover
Compell'd his own Lips to dicover,
The very Dictates of his Heart,
Declaring, Agnes, makes it Smart.

div.p:
Elvira did not much tick on the Nicety of Poetry in the lat Veres, and provided, they had
but the Effect which he wih'd for, he requir'd no more.

Her Impatiency would not permit her to tay till the next day to Publih them. She went to the Princes Apartment, who was gone forth to walk, and paing to her very Cloet without being perceiv'd, he conveyed the Paper in a Book which the Princes did uually read, and Retired very well atisfy'd with her good Succes.

So oon as Contantia was return'd, he went into her Cloet, where he found the Book open and in it thoe Veres that hould cot her o dear. The Prince's Character was well known to her; but beides the cruel Confirmation of all that he had feared, he learn'd that it was Agnes of Catro, whoe ole Friendhip could conolate her Affliction, who was the caue of it. She did Read an hundred times over the ame thing, eeking to belye her own Eyes and Reaon; but perceiving too well that he was not deceiv'd,
and conulting her Thoughts on this Adventure, he found her elf much more poet with Sorrow then with Anger, when he conider'd that Don Pedre as Amorous as he was, had till preerv'd his Love in Secrecy. After having pittyed him without Condemning, her natural tendernes did caue her to hed a deluge of Tears, and did inpire her with the deign of concealing all her Grief.

She had certainly done it by the Power of an Extraordinary Virtue, had not the Prince enter'd with extream hat, he miing his Veres at his awaking, and fearing they hould light into Indicreet Hands, he came into the Palace diturb'd with this Los, came to Contantia, oberv'd her Humid Eyes, and tay'd his own on thoe unlucky Veres, which had newly ecap'd from his Paion.

He preently grew Pale, and appear'd o Concern'd that the
Generous Princes was more enible of his then of her own Misfortune: Madam, aid he, with Amazement, whence have you that Paper? It cannot come but from ome Enemy of your quiet and mine, reply'd Contantia, it is the Work of your own Hand, My Lord, and doubtles of the Motion of your Heart alo; but fear nothing, if my Tendernes would make it pas for a Crime, that ame Tendernes which nothing can alter, would prevent it in me.

Contantia's Moderation did erve but to render the Prince more Confounded. How Generous you are Madam continu'd he, and how Unfortunate am I! Some Tears did Accompany thoe Words, and the Princes who Paionately Lov'd him, was o enibly mov'd with them that for along pace they both remain'd Mute. At lat Contantia broke ilence, and hewing him, what
Elvira had caus'd to be added; You have betray'd your elf, My Lord, continu'd he, you have been over-heard, and your Secret is known. It was in that very Moment that the Princes whole Strength did Abandon him, and that his preent Condition became worthy of Compaion. He could not forgive himelf that Unvoluntary Crime which he had committed againt the Amiable Innocent Agnes; and though he was convinc'd of Contantia's Bounty, the Vexation which this Prudent, and Modet Maid might receive from his Conduct, did carry it above all other Coniderations.

The Princes who was examining of him with her Eyes, perceived o many marks of depair on his Face, that he fear'd the effects of it, and obligingly holding forth her hand to him; I promie you, my Lord, aid he, that I will never complain of you, and that Agnes hall ever be dear to me. You
hall not find me inclin'd to make you reproaches; and not being capable of poeing your heart, Il'e ret atisfyed in endeavouring to render my elf worthy of it. Don Pedre more concern'd than before, bowed a Knee before Contantia, kis'd with repect that hand which he had given him, and, perhaps did forget Agnes for a moment.

But Love did oon put a top to thee mall Progrees of Hymen, That fatal Planet which did predominate over Don Pedre's Fate, had not yet pent all it's malignity; and one moment of Agnes his ight, oon added new Forces to his Paion.
That fair Maids conent had had no hare in her victory, her eyes were exact and dicerning, but they ought not in the Princes eyes, for that which they would have dicovered to her.

She never did ue to be long ditant from Contantia, wherefore Don Pedre was no ooner gone out of the Cloet but he came into it,
and finding the Princes mov'd and melting, he doubted not but that he had ome jut Caue of Sorrow; he put her elf in the ame poture, that the Prince had been but a moment before, and expreing her diturbance with concerned Looks, Madam, aid he, in the name of your Bounties, conceal not from me the Caue of that Trouble I find in you. Alas! Agnes, reply'd the beautiful Princes, what is it you would know, and what am I to tell you? The Prince is in Love. That hand which he once gave me, was no preent of his heart, and all the advantage of this Allyance, will but make me the Sacrifice. The Prince in Love! reply'd Agnes, with an Amazement mixt with Indignation: And what Fatal Beauty can dipute with yours the Empire of an heart o jutly due to you? Ah! Madam, all my repect cannot hinder me from murmuring againt him. Do not accue him of any thing, reply'd Contantia, he
trives all that he can, and I am more oblig'd to his endeavouring to remain faithful to me, than if I really did enjoy his affections. It is not ufficient to fight for to overcome, and the Prince does more in that dipoition he finds himelf in, than I ought to have hoped for. In fine, he is my Husband, an amiable Husband, to which there is nothing wanting, but that which I have not been able to inpire in him, that is, a Paion which had rendred me too happy. Ah! Madam, cryed out Agnes de Catro, tranported with her affection for Contantia: He is a blind Prince, who knows not the precious advantage which he poees. It mut needs be that he knows more, reply'd the Princes, modetly: But Madam, continued Agnes, is there any thing either in Portugal, or in all Spain, that can be compar'd to you? And not to reckon on the Qualities of your Peron, can thoe of your mind be ufficiently prais'd?
—My Dear Agnes, replyed the Princes ighing, he that takes my Husbands heart from me, has but too much wherewith to plead his Excue, eeing it is of thee that Fortune has made ue to give me that woeful blow: Yes, Agnes the Prince loves thee, and that Merit which I know to be in thee, puts a top to my Complaints, not admitting of the leat reentment.

The Beauteous Agnes little expected what the Princes had aid to her. Thunder and Lightning, had les urpris'd and abas'd her, he remain'd long Speechles; but at lat fixing her looks on Contantia; What ay you Madam, reply'd he, and what thoughts have you had of me? What hould I be capable of betraying you? And in coming here fill'd with Zeal for the quiet of your Life I hould bring with me but a direful Poion, that hould diturb it? How hould I detet that little of Beauty which is found in me, (though
without any deign in me of making of it known) and that unfortunate day in which I firt beheld the Prince! But Madam it cannot be me certainly that the Heavens have choen to travers you. They are not o much my Enemy to put me to o evere a Tryal, and if I was that Odious Peron, there would be no Exiles nor Torments to which I would not condemn my elf. 'Tis Elvira, Madam, whom the Prince has formerly Lov'd, before your Marriage, and even before Blanch's Divorce; ome indicreet reports have been made you concerning that intregue of his Younger days; but that which has happen'd in the time of Blanch, has no relation to you. It is mot certain that Don Pedre Loves, you anwered the Princes, and I have vanity enough to believe that of truth, there is none but you in all Spain that can dipute it with me, but his ecret is dicover'd, and he has not deny'd it. What, reply'd
the Beauteous Agnes, with a greater urprie it is from himelf, that you have receiv'd the Intelligence of his weaknes? Then did Constantia hew her the Veres, and there never was any dipair like hers.

While they were in that ad converation, Impatient Elvira, who was deirous to learn the effects of her Practices came again to the Princes, where he had a free acces, he was not hindred from going to her very Cloet, and her Preence drew a rednes on the cheeks of two retles and afflicted Perons which deired not her Company, he had the atisfaction of oberving Constantia to lay aide thoe Veres, which the Princes had not een without her Malice, and of an imoderate Sorrow in her Eyes, and in Agnee's alo. She remain'd there jut o long as needed to inform her that he had ucceeded well, but the Princes who deired not uch an obtinate Witnes of the troubles he was in at that
preent, order'd to be left alone, Elvira went out, and Agnes de Catro retired at the ame time alo.

It was in her own Chamber, that examining more at large her Adventure, he found it as cruel as Death it elf. She Lov'd Contantia with a true Affection, and till then, had not had for the Prince of Portugal but an eteem mixed with that admiration which could not be deny'd to his Excellent Qualities, and conidering herelf with extremity of Grief, as the caue of the Sorrows of uch a Princes to whoe Bountys he was o Indebted, he Employd all the Night in Tears and Complaints, which ufficiently reveng'd Contantia of thee Evils which he caus'd her to feel.

The Prince was no les diturb'd, his Wives generoity increaed his remores, without diminihing his love. He did fear, not without great likelines, that they who had
poet Contantia with thoe Veres, would alo acquaint the King of his paion, from whom he could not expect o great an Indulgency, and he would freely part with his Life to free himelf from that extremity.

The afflicted Contantia did Languih in a deplorable condition, he could not ee any thing in thoe Perons that caus'd her Misfortune, but what was apt to move her tender affections. At lat Jealouy deign'd, (but vainly) to combat that tendency which he had, to Love them. The Prince was not les dear unto her, and he could not be enible either of hatred or indifferency towards her rival.

While that thee three uneay Perons did abandon themelves unto their Melancholy, Elvira who was reolved not to let her vengeance remain imperfect was contriving by what means he might accomplih it. Her Brother on
whom he did depend, did hew her a great affection, and gueing that the Loves of Don Pedre and Agnes of Catro would not be approv'd of by the King, he dicover'd it to Don Alvares, who was not Ignorant of the former that the Prince had had with his Siter. He found himelf mot powerfully concern'd in the news he had told him, through a ecret paion which he had for Agnes, which he had concealed in his own Breat leat it hould in any ort thwart the mooth coure of his good Fortune, and he was in expectation of a continuation of Don Alfones Favours, whereby to render his Heart, a more coniderable preent.

He concealed not from his Siter a Mitery which he had found very difficult to keep ecret, and it prov'd a duplication of vexation to her, to find Agnes the Sovereign of all thoe Hearts over which he had any pretentions.

Don Alvares was one of thoe Ambitious men that are o without Moderation, Proud without Generoity, of cruel inclination, and who to attain his ends, could not ee any thing, that was either difficult or Illigitimate. He Naturaly lov'd not the Prince who in all reaon was to poes the firt place in Don Alfone's Heart, and who et limits unto Don Alvare's good Fortune. But he undertood that he was his Rival, Jealouie increas'd his hatred, and he intreated Elvira to employ all her cares to cros an engagement which could not but be oppoite to his deigns. She promied him all aid and aitance, though he was not atisfied, as to her own concerns, and he rely'd on her promie and dexterity.

Don Alvares, who had enibly felt the Prince of Portugal's concurrence in his amours, had no other thoughts but of thwarting and oppoing his Merits. He had no
handom preence, neither was he of an agreable temper, and Don Pedre had thoe advantages, and poes'd divers others alo, but being Husband to Contantia, and that he wholly depended on a Father who was abolute, and that Don Alvares was under no retraint, and Mater of a coniderable Fortune, he truted his good Fortune on that core.

He knew well that Don Pedre's Love could not but inpire Don Alfone with a violent anger; and being over diligent in doing evil, his firt Care was to inform him of it. After he had given ufficient Leaure to his anger to roue unto that Pitch he would have it, he poke for himelf, and oon did render the King Protector of his Paion.

Though Don Alvares had no other Merits with the King of Portugal, than a continual blind Complacency, he had poured all hi • Favours upon him, and in that
State in which the Kings Liberality had placed him; few Women could well refue his Allegiance, Don Alfone did aure him the connuation of his Friendhip and Favour, and did aure him that he himelf hould looe his authority, or that he would make him Mater of Agnes.

Don Alvares, perfectly learned in the Art of managing his Mater did anwer his lat bounties with a profound ubmiion, and very fit to continue them. He had never poken to Agnes what he did feel for her, but he then thought it time to break forth, and immediately ought after the means to perform it.

The galantry of Coimbria which lay in oblivion did then roue it elf up again. The King to pleaure Don Alvares under a pretence of diverting of Contantia, did order ome public ports, and it was his Pleaure that all things hould appear very magnificently.

Ever ince the adventure of the Veres Don Pedre had endeavor'd all means to contrain himelf and of appearing les concern'd; but in the bottom he till equally uffer'd, and it was not without great uneaines that he fitted himelf for the Juting. And eing that he could not appear o Publicly with Agnes's Colours, he took thoe of the Princes, without any Motto or Agreements.

p.U: et himelf off with Agnes de Catro's Liveries, and that beautiful Maid, who found no comfort in what the Princes had aid, had this further addition of Sorrow.

div.p:
Don Pedre did appear in the Lit extream graceful, and Don Alvares who look'd upon this day as his own, did appear all Glittering with Gold and Jewels mixed with blew, which was Agnes's Colour, and his Equipage was all over prinkled with inflamed Hearts, and Love Knots, with aboundance
of double As; his Motto was a Cupid breaking out of a Cloud with thee four Veres under it.

q.l: My Bahful Love, Banih all fear,
From your concealing Cloud appear.
For nows the time, mot Charming Eyes
To know that heart, you made your Prie.

div.p:
Don Alvares's Pride was laid humble at Don Pedre's Feet, who bore him down with twenty more, and he alone carried the honour of the day. At Night there was a gallant appearance at Contantia's appartment, where Agnes had not been without an expres and abolute order from the Princes. She did appear very negligently dret, though till charming with Vexation, he had een her Name and Colours us'd by Don Alvares, in a public Solemnity, and if her Heart was capable of any tendernes it was not for uch a Peron as he, that her Nicety deign'd them. She look'd on him with a Contempt, which hinder'd him not from preing much upon
her, and he was forc'd to give Ear to what he had a mind to ay.

She was not rude, but her Coldnes would have repuls'd all other but Alvares: Madam, aid he to her, o oon as he could not be heard but by her elf, I had till this preent concealed that Paion which you had Inpired me with; in fear of your dipleaure; but it has forc'd my repect, and I can no longer conceal it from you. I have made no reflections on your Actions, reply'd Agnes, with all th • indifferency imaginable, and if you offend me, you wrong me the more in deiring my taking Notice of it. This Coldnes is of evil Omen to me, reply'd Don Alvares, and if you have not this day taken notice of my love, it is to be fear'd, that you will never approve of it. Alas! what time have you choen to hew i • me, contin'd Agnes, does it o much Honour me, that you hew it with o mu ••…
care, and do you believe me o greedy of Glory, as to Apire at that which derives from you? You have ill maintain'd it in the Juts, and if it is that vanity which prompts you on, you will make no great Progres in a Soul which loves not hame. Though you were in Poeion of all the Advantages which the Prince has merited, yet you ought to reflect on what you are doing, and it is not a Peron like me that can be mov'd by uch repectles enterpries.

Don Alfone's Favourite was too Proud, to hear Agnes thus pake without Colour; but his deign being to render her flexible, and not to anger her; he conceal'd his Reentment; and taking Notice of the Obervation which he had made on Don Pedre's Tryumph with an Addition of Jealouy. If, I have not overcome at the Jut, • eply'd he, I am not les Amorous, <> les capable of Succes in other ••••… ions.

They were interrupted; but from that day, Don Alvares, who had gone over the firt difficulties, no longer oberv'd any Meaures, and Perecuted Agnes, to whom the Kings Protection Inpir'd not the leat coniderations for him.

Don Pedre was till Ignorant of the means by which thoe Veres which he had lot in the Garden had fallen into Contantia's hands. The Princes appearing very Indulgent to him, he had no other trouble but for Agne's Interet. Don Alvare's Love, that was now o known did perplex him, and if he had follow'd his own Dictates, he had not left her expos'd to the Perecutions of that unworthy Rival. On the other hand he fear'd that the King hould be inform'd of his Paion; but he did not then reflect enough on Elvira, to fear her Reentments.

She Burnt with a deire to ruine Agnes, againt whom all her Poion
was tirr'd up, and he was not tyred with making daily new reports to her Brother, auring him though he had no proofs for it, that Agnes did anwer to the Prince's tendernes, that it was the true caue of Contantia's Grief, and that if that Princes hould dye of it, Don Pedre might Marry Agnes, infine he did o irritate her Brothers Jealouie, that he run, to hew it wholly to Don Alfone, who Trembled with Anger at it; My dear Alvares, aid he, to him, Marry her, that Beauty that is o dangerous, and let your Poeion ecure both yours and my quiet. If I have protected you in other occaions, Judge what a buines of uch Importance to me can make me undertake. Act without any reerve. The Powers of the Kingdom are in your Power, and all that I poes hall be certainly at your dipoal, provided you but render your elf. Mater of Agne's Detiny.

Don Alvares well pleas'd with his Mater, took hold of all the Authority that he gave him. He really Lov'd Agnes, and was loath to come at firt to any violence; but he promis'd himelf to be beyond all Management if he till continu'd inenible.

Mean time Agnes de Catro highly importun'd with his Aiduities, deperate at Contantia's Griefs, and peradventure molified by thoe which he cau • 'd the Prince to uffer, did take a Reolution worthy of her Virtue. As Amiable as was Don Pedre, he could not ee in him but the Husband of a Princes that was mot dear to her, and far from eeking to improve that Power which he had over his Heart, he thought of nothing but abenting her elf from Coimbria. Don Alvare's Paion, which he would not favour did furnih her with a pretence, and pres'd on with the fears of cauing at lat a Divorce, mot
Cruel betwixt the Prince and his Spoue, he found out Constantia in a perplexity that all her cares could not conceal.

The Princes eaily oberv'd it, and their common misfortune having not alter'd her Friendhip. What's the matter with you Agnes, aid he, with her wonted weetnes, and what new misfortune does your orrow come to inform me of; That Attachment which I have for you, Madam, reply'd Agnes, does put me to a Cruel Tryal, and pouring forth a Flood of Tears, I had limited the happines of my Life in the hopes of pending of it near your Peron, yet I find that I mut Tranport omewhere ele an Uunfortunate Face, that renders me but ill Offices, and it is to obtain from you that Permiion, that I come to Embrace your Knees, looking on you as on my Sovereign.

Contantia was o urpris'd and o mov'd at Agne's propoition,
that he remain'd Speechles; for ome Moments, ome incere Tears expres'd her firt grief, and after he had ufficiently hed them to give Agnes a ufficient Mark of her Tendernes, he fixed her Sorrowful Eyes upon her, and obligingly holding forth her hand to her, then you will go, my dear Agnes, continu'd he, and further expoe me unto the orrow of eeing you no more. Alas, Madam reply'd that amyable Maid, Conceal from the Mierable Agnes a Bounty which increaes her Sorrows. It is not I that would depart, it is my Duty and my Reaon that will have it o, and thoe days that I hall pas abent from you, cannot promie me any thing o agreeable as to inpire me uch a deign if I found not my elf abolutely compell'd to it. I cannot be Ignorant of what paes at Coimbria, and I hould be an Accomplice to thoe Unjutices which are there committed hould I reide
there any longer — Ah! I know your Virtue, cryed out Constantia, and you may remain here in all ecurity, if I tay you here, and whatever does happen I hall never accue you of any thing. We mut not promie our elves any thing of future, Madam, reply'd Agnes orrowfully, and I hall till remain ufficiently Guilty, o long as my preence hall entertain uch thoughts as cannot be accounted Innocent. Moreover Madam, Don Alvare's importunities are unufferable, and finding in my elf nothing but Averion againt him, that the King protects his Inolency, and that he is in a Condition of undertaking much, my flight is abolutely neceary; But Madam, though he poees nothing but what is odious to me, I call Heaven to Witnes, that if I could Cure the Prince by Marrying of him, I hould not defer it one moment, and finding in my mind, the Conolation of having
Sacrific'd my elf for my Princes, I hould bear it without any Murmur; But in fine though I hould be Don Alvare's Wife, Don Pedre would till have the ame Eyes, and I find nothing better then to go hide my elf in ome Corner of the World, where I hall certainly Live without Comfort; but where I hould preerve my innocency. All that Jutice which you can find in this deign, anwer'd the Princes, hall not oblige me to approve of it. Would your Abence retore me Don Pedre's Heart, and would he not fly with you? His Cares, are mine, my Life is link'd with his, reduce him not then to a dipair, if you, love me. I know you, I once again declare it to you, and what power oever you have over the Prince's heart, I hall not permit that you hould leave us.

Though Agnes believ'd he had a perfect Knowledg of Contantia, he did not expect uch a fund of
Virtue, he found her elf the more Unfortunate by it, and the Prince more Guilty. Oh! Widom, Oh! Bounty! beyond Example cry'd he out; why do not the Cruel Fates afford you all that you deerve. You are the Arbiter of all my Actions, continu'd he, kiing one of Constantia's hands, I will not do but what you pleae; but I beeech you to think on what reaon ought to prompt you to precribe to me.

Don Pedre, who had not yet een the Princes that day, came in jut then, and finding them both diturb'd he inquired after the reaon with ome earnetnes. My Lord reply'd Contantia, the too Wie and too crupulous Agnes fears the Effects of her Beauty, and will no longer live at Coimbria and it is on that Account, which cannot be pleaing to me, that he is asking my Advice. At this dicoure the Prince grew pale, and with more diturbance then either of them had.
Agnes cannot err, aid he, in following your Counels; Madam, and I leave you with free Liberty of given them to her. He preently went out, and the Princes whoe heart he did o abolutely poes, not being able to conceal her dicontent. My dear Agnes, continu'd he, though my atisfaction was not chain'd to the ight of you, I hould till deire it on Don Pedre's account. It is, the only Advantage that his Unfortunate Love can hope for, and hould I not be with Jutice reputed barbarous, if I hould contribute towards his being depriv'd of it? But that object is but a Poion to him, reply'd Agnes, and what hould I do my Dear Princes, if after o much retraint, his Mouth hould add to thoe Evils which I have already felt, that of hearing him pake of his flame? You hould hear him without running him into dipair, added Contantia, and I hould charge that new Obligation on my
Account. You would have me to wait for events that I fear, Madam, anwer'd Agnes, I hall obey you. But ye jut Heavens! If they are Fatal, punih not for them an Innocent Heart. Thus ended that Converation. Agnes retir'd into her Chamber; but it was without hopes of being more at eae.

That which Don Pedre had learn'd of her deign, produc'd a trange Diturbance in his mind, he wih'd he did not Love her, and deired Death with great earnetnes, but it was too late for him to wih againt what the Fates had decreed, and whatever he endeavour'd to reolve himelf to bear as to the Abence of Agnes, his Love never had the Power to conent to it.

After he had long trove, he firmly reolv'd to do that which he would not have Agnes to do. His Courage did reproach to him that idle Life which he lead during his happiet years,
and repreenting to the King that their Allies, and even the Prince Don John Manuel his Father-in-Law, had buines in hand which required his preence upon the Frontiers, he eaily obtain'd the Liberty of making that Voyage, unto which the Princes could make no oppoition.

Agnes did ee him depart without any orrow: but that did not proceed from any Averion. Then did Don Alvares convert his firt importunity into an open Perecution. He omitted nothing to touch Agne's Heart, and for ome coniderable time employ'd none but the. Arms of Love, but finding that his repect and ubmiion were fruitles, he took another Coure, and fram'd mot trange Deigns.

The King deferring all things to his Advices, he did eaily inpire in him what he pleas'd; he complain'd of Agne's Ingratitude, and fail'd not to let him know that it was but through her too great
enibility for the Prince that he was o inenible to him, o that Don Alfone apt to be irritated, reiterated all thoe Promies, which he had already made him.

The King of Portugal, had not yet dicours'd Agnes in Favour of Don Alvares, and not doubting but that his Will would overcome all orts of Obtacles, he ought after an opportunity of Entertaining her, and putting her at ome ditance from thoe that might over-hear them, I did think Don Alvares to be of a ufficient Merit, he aid, to obtain ome mall hare in your Eteem, and I did not think it neceary that I hould require it of you for him, I know you are all charming, but he has nothing unworthy of you, and on the leat Reflection you might make of the Choice that my Friendhip has made of him, amongt all the ret of my Courtiers, you would doubtles readily do him more Jutice. His Fortune is not to be
diputed, ince I am the Protector of it. He is of a Noble Birth, his Courage does him Honour, he adores you, and in my opinion o many reaons ought to over-come your Scorns.

Agnes's Heart was o little dipos'd to give it elf to Don Alvares, that all the King of Portugal's Exagerations prevail • d nothing in his behalf. Though Don Alvares were without Merits, Sir, She reply'd, he poees ufficiently of Advantages in thoe Bounties with which your Majety does Honour him, to upply all other defects. It is not to find any defects in him that I anwer not his wihes; But, Sir, through what Obligation would he have me to Love him, if the Heavens have not furnihed me with a tender Soul? and why does he pretend that I hould ubmit my elf to him, when that nothing ought to be more dear to me then Liberty? You are neither o free nor o inenible
as you peak, reply'd Don Alfone, bluhing with Anger, and if your Heart was free from all orts of Affections it might receive a more reaonable one then that which poees it. But Imprudent Maid, that you are guided by an ill fate, added he with Fury, what can you pretend from Don Pedre? Hither to I have conceal'd the orrow that his and your weaknes have caus'd me; but it has not been the les violent for that; and ince you oblige me to let it break forth, I ought to tell you that though my Son were not tyed to Contantia, his Marriage hould never conern you. Renounce thoe vain Ideas, and take a coure that may cure him and jutifie your elf.

The Courageous Agnes, was carce Mitris of her firt Tranport, at a Dicoure o full of Scorn, but calling her Virtue to econd her Anger, he overcame her elf by her own reaon,
conidering the wrong which he utained not as proceeding from a great King, but from a Man blinded and wholly poes'd by Don Alvares. She thought him not worthy of her reentment. Her fair Eyes were animated with a parkling brightnes, which witneed the purity of her intentions, and fixing them on Don Alfone; if the Prince Don Pedre has failings aid he, with an Air that inclin'd omething to didain, he has never inform'd me of them, and I do not believe that I have contributed to them.
