To cure your ditrut, and et my Honour afe, I hall live at a ditance from him, and all that belongs to you. Yes, Sir, I hall contentedly leave the aboad of Coimbria, and as to that Man o dear to you, added he, with a Noble boldnes, of which the King of Portugal was very enible, that Favorite, who is o worthy to poes the mot tender affections of a great Prince, I do aure
you that in what part of the World oever my Fortune leads me, I hall not carry the leat thought of him with me. At thee words, he made a profound Bow, and did o uddainly ditance herelf from Don Alfone, that he could not oppoe himelf againt her retirement.

He believ'd more then ever that he did Favour Don Pedres paion, and pas'd into Contantias appartment, to inpire her with the ame thought; but he was not capable of receiving uch impreions, and following her Natural inclination, he generouly defended Agnes's Virtue, Don Alfone, vexed to find her o well dipos'd on her rivals account, whom he would have her to hate, did murmur againt her goodnes, and went to joyn his anger to Don Alvare's rage who no longer wa • Mater of himelf after he had een that his Mater's Negotiation wa • of no effect. That Proud one
braves me, Sir, aid he, and contemns the Honour that your bounties have made her, that I might renounce o fatal a paion; but I mut love her againt my will, and though that Flame hould cot me my Life, I plainly feel that I can not put it out. What i'st that I can do for you? replyed Don Alfone? Alas! Sir, reply'd, Don Alvares, that which I can never hope for from Proud Agne's conent. Well, added the King eeing that I mut not Publicly authorie any Violence in the Center of my Kingdom, chue from amongt all my Subjects uch as thou halt Judge mot capable of erving thee; carry off that Beauty which charms thee, and if he yeilds not to thy Love, make ue of all that force can do for thee, to force her to Marry thee.

Don Alvares ravih'd with uch a propoition, which at once did Flatter his reentments and his
love cat himelf at Don Alfone's Feet, did expres his acknowlegments to him, et forward his Zeal, with new protetations, and thought no longer but to employ his unjut authority againt Agnes.

Don Pedre had been abent above three Months, when Don Alvares did undertake that which the King had advis'd him to do. Though the Princes moderation was well known to him, he fear'd his preence, and was loath to expect the return of a rival with whom nothing had yet been diputed.

One night that the orrowful Agnes, full of her daily Diturbances, was in vain expecting leep, ome unknown men, whoe teps were well order'd did take her out of the Palace, and after carried her out of Coimbria, without being hindred by any Obtacle, he could not well tell on whom to fix her Supicions. Don Alvares
eem'd too powerful to eek for his Satisfaction after uch a manner, and he did not taxe with this attempt a Prince of whom he had too good an Opinion. All that he could ay, did not hinder her ill adventure; he was carried away with dilligence, and before day, he was already coniderably ditant from the City.

At the firt Glimps of day, he look'd on all thoe that urrounded her, not knowing o much as one; and perceiving well, that both out-cries, and tears, were in vain to uch cruel minds, he reted contented in imploring the protection of Heaven, and o abandon'd her elf to her Conductors.

While he was overwhelm'd with Sorrow, and uncertain of her doom, he perceiv'd a Body of Hore to advance towards the Troops that conducted her; The ravihers did not avoid it, beleiving it to be Don Alvares; but coming
near, they perceiv'd that it was the Prince of Portugal, who without any knowledg of this opportunity of erving Agnes, was returning to Coimbria full of her Idea, after he had perform'd all that he was to do in his expedition.

Agnes, who did not expect him alter'd her mind, and thought that it was by his orders that he was forc'd away. Ah! my Lord, aid he, in that thought, was it you that was thus to tare me from the Princes? and mut o cruel a blow fall on me from a hand o dear to her? What will you do with a mierable wretch who eeks but for Death? and why will you Tarnih the Glory of your life, by a deign o unworthy of you?

That Language did no les urprie the Prince, then the ight of Agnes had done. He Apprehended that he had been forc'd away, and intantly reenting the mot peircing trokes of Anger, he gave
her to undertand with one ingle look, that he was not the bae author of her grief. I, tare you from Contantia who are all her joy, aid he, what thoughts have you of Don Pedre? If you ee me here, I am wholly Innocent of that violence which is offer'd you, and which I hall prevent. Then did he turn himelf towards the Ravihers; but his preence had already dipers'd them. He order'd his Men to purue them, and at leat to eie ome from whom he might learn the authority by which they did Act.

During this, Agnes was not les confus'd then before, he admir'd the conduct of her Fortune, who brought the Prince at the very moment that he was o ueful to her. Her equity did oon redres the wrong which her ditruts had caus'd her to do him. She felt ome joy to have ecaped a Misfortune which appear'd o certain to her, but it was no quiet
joy, when he conider'd that her deliverer was her lover too, and uch a lover as deerv'd her entire acknowledgments, but that alo owed his Heart to the mot amiable Princes in the World.

Don Alvares, who fear'd being een near to Coimbria, and who delay'd Proecuting of Agnes till he was at a ditance from it, had confided his deign to ome Friends, which he jug'd capable to execute it, and that had done it had not the Prince interpos'd.

During the time that his Men were peruing of the Ravihers of Agnes, he remain'd almot alone with her, and though he had reolv'd always to avoid her preence, his Fortitude could not withtand o fair an occaion. Madam aid he, is it poible that Men born amongt thoe that obey us, hould be capable of offending you? It was not to the care of Punihing uch a Crime that I thought my elf reerv'd; but ince the Heavens have permitted
that you hould receive it, I mut perih or caue you to forget it. My Lord, reply'd Agnes, more mov'd at this dicoure, then at Don Alvares's enterprie, thoe that want repect for the Princes and for you, may be dipens'd from having any for me. I no longer doubt but that Don Alvares is the Author of this attempt, and I judge what I may expect from him, by that which his importunity has made me uffer. He is certain of the Kings protection, and he deigns to make him partner in his crimes; But my Lord the Heavens have conducted you mot happily here for me, and to you do I owe the Liberty of again erving the Princes. You would do for Contantia, that which is impoible not to perform for you, reply'd Don Pedre, your goodnes binds you to her, and others Fortunes does for ever engage them to you.

The modet Agnes, who dreaded this dicoure, as much as the danger which had been prevented, made no other anwer then to cat down her looks, and the Prince who undertood her diorder, left her to pake to two of his Men, who brought him back one of thoe that Don Alvares had employ'd. He pardon'd him, and did not think that he hould punih him, for having obey'd a man, who was made Almighty through his Fathers weaknes.

After this, Agnes was brought back to Coimbria where her being forc'd away, began to be highly cenur'd. The Princes, was infinitely Afflicted, and at firt believ'd it was a conequence of that deign which that Fair Maid had expres'd to her of her retirement; but ome Women that waited on her, having declar'd that violence had been offer'd to her, Contantia went and made her complaints to the King, who gave no great attention to the relation.
Madam, aid he, let that Fatal Plague that deprives you of your Husbands Heart, be remov'd from you, and be not Afflicted at her abence, rather thank Heaven with me for it.
The generous Princes took Agne's part, with a great deal of courage, and he was till diputing with the King, when Don Pedre, came to Coimbria.

The firt object which truck his Eyes was Don Alvares, who was croing one of the Courts of the Palace, in the midt of a Cloud of Courtiers, which his Favour did faten to him. The ight of him caus'd Don Pedre to be diturb'd, but the ight of Don Pedre and Agnes gave him much greater troubles, he eaily guet that it was Don Pedre who had recued her from his Men, and if his fury could have Acted all that it would have done, it had produc'd very ad Effects, at that very Moment.

p.U: aid the Prince to him, is it thus that you employ that authority which the King my Father gives you? have you receiv'd Employs, and Power from his bounty, but to employ them in perfidiounes and in abuing of Women? Were you ignorant of that interet which the Princes has in this Maid, and did you not know what a tender affectionate eteem he has for her? No, reply'd Don Alvares, with uch inolency as did quite anger the Prince, I was not Ignorant of it, nor of that hare your Heart has in it. Bae wretch, reply'd the Prince, neither that favour which thou abues, nor that inolence which makes thee p • ate, hall hinder me from Punihing of thee, were thou worthy of my blows; but there are other ways to humble thy Pride, and it is not uch an arm as mine that mut take on it the vile employ of Chatiing o mean a thing as thou art.

div.p: Don Pedre went forwards at thee words, and left Don Alvares in uch a rage as cannot be expres'd mad to ee an enterprie fail, which he believ'd o ure, and at the Princes corn of him, and promis'd to himelf to Sacrifice all to his revenge.
Though Don Alfone lov'd his Son, he was too much prepoes'd with his paion, to Pardon him what he had newly done, and he did condemn an action of great Jutice, as if it had been an heinous Crime.
Elvira who the weetnes of hope had flatter'd for ome moments, beheld Agne's return with a mot enible Sorrow, which left her no other thoughts then of tirring up her Brother to revenge.

In fine the Prince did ee Don Alfone, but intead of being receiv'd by him with that joy which he owed to the good ucces of his expedition, he hewed him nothing but a cloe Anger. After he had
render'd, him his firt repects, and and exact account of his proceedings he poke to him of that violence which had been offer'd Agnes de Castro, and complain'd of it in the Princes's Name as well as his own. You ought to be ilent in that repect, reply'd the King, and that motive which caues you to pake, is o hameful that I bluh and igh for you. What concerns it you whether that maid, whoe preence troubles me, be remov'd from hence or not? o long as I would have it o. But Sir, reply'd Don Pedre, was open force, craft and the night Seaon, to be employ'd, where the leat of your orders was ufficient? Agnes had obey'd you, and if he remains here till, peradventure it is againt her will. However, Sir, Contantia is offended at it, and without the fear of dipleaing you, which, retains me, that action had not remain'd unpunih'd. How happy are you,
reply'd Don Alfone, with a cornful mile, to make ue of Contantia's name in this, to maintain the interets of your Heart. Do you think I know them not, and that that unfortunate Princes, looks on the wrong you do her with indifferency? never more mention Agnes to me continu'd he, in a evere Tone, be atisfy'd that I Pardon you for what is pas'd, and think well on the kindnes which I have for Don Alvares, when ere you deign any thing againt him. No, Sir, anwered the anger'd Prince, I hall not pake any more of Agnes; but neither Contantia, nor I will any longer uffer her to be any more expos'd unto the inolency of your Favorite.

The King of Portugal had like to have broke forth at this Dicoure; but ome Reliques of Prudence prevented it. Retire, aid he to Don Pedre, and go make Reflections on what I can do, and what you owe me.

During this Converation, Agnes was receiving from the Princes, and from all the Ladies of the Court, great Expreions of Joy and Friendhip, Contantia aw again her Husband, with a great deal of atisfaction and far from being orry at what he had lately done for Agnes, he privately return'd him thanks for it, and till was the ame towards him, nothwithtanding all the Jealouy which was endeavour'd to be inpired in her.

Don Alvares who found in his Siter, a Maliciounes worthy of his trut, did not conceal his fury from her. After he had made vain attempts to moderate it, in blotting Agnes out of his Heart, eeing that his Dieae was incurable, he made him undertand, that o long as Contantia hould not be Jealous, there was no hopes. That if Agnes hould once be upected by her, he would not fail of Abandoning her, and that then it
would be eaie to get Satisfaction, the Prince being now o Proud of Contantia's indulgency. In giving this Advice to her Brother, he promis'd to erve him effectually, and having no need of any body but her elf, to perform ill things, he recommended Don Alvares to manage well the King.
Four Years were pas'd in that Melancholy tation, and the Princes beides her firt dead Child, and Ferdinand who was till Living, had brought two Daughters into the World.

Some Days after Don Pedre's return, Elvira, who was mot Dextrous in the Art of well Governing any Wicked Deign, did gain one of the Servants which belong'd to Contantia's Chamber; he firt poke her fair, than overwhelm'd her with Preents and Gifts, and finding in her as ill a Dipoition as in her elf, he readily reolv'd to employ her.

After he was ure of her, he
compos'd a Letter, which was after Writ over again in an unknown Hand, which he depoited in that Maids Hands, that he might deliver it to Constantia with the firt opportunity, telling her that Agnes had dropt it; This was the Subtance of it.

I employ not my own Hand to Write to you, for Reaons that I hall acquaint you with. How happy am I to have overcome all your Scruples! And what Happines hall I find in the Progres of our Intreague! The whole Coure of my Life, hall continually repreent to you the incerity of my Affections; pray think on the ecret Converation that I require of you. I fancy till, that all Perons that approach you, deprive me of omething of my due. I dare not pake to you in public; Therefore come this Night where you know, I conjure you to it by all that I have uffered; Mention no more Contantia to me; he
mut be atisfy'd with my Eteem, ince that my Heart could be none but Yours.

The fale Portuguie Servant, obey'd Elvira exactly, the very next day perceiving Agnes coming from the Princes he brought the Letter to Constantia, who receiv'd it, and found in it, that which he was far from thinking on. Never did tendernes produce o orrowful an Effect as then. Alas! they are both Guilty, aid he ighing, and notwithtanding that Tendency which I find in my Heart to jutifie them, my reaon mut needs Condemn them. Unfortunate Princes, Sorrowful Subject of Fortunes Capricios, why cant thou not Dye, eeing thou art not of a Humor to Revenge thy elf! Don Pedre, ought you to give me your Hand, when you knew you could not give me your Heart? And thou fair and ungreateful Agnes, wer't thou born to produce the Evil of my Days, and to be the caue of my
Death? After he had given ome Moments unto the violence of her Sorrow, he call'd to her that Peron who had brought her the Letter, charg'd her not to pake of it to any body, and then order'd that no body whatoever hould be Admitted into her Chamber.

Then did he with more Liberty think on him whom he could not inpire with Love, and on her that betray'd her. The trouble of her Soul did not hinder her from eeking ome means to excue them. And deirous to do all that he could for Don Pedre, he took a firm Reolution of not complaining of him.
Elvira was not long, without being Inform'd of what pas'd, and of the Princes's Sorrow, whence he hoped for all that he could wih.

Agnes far from imagining any uch Storm, return'd to Contantia, and learning her indipoition, he
pas'd the ret of the day at her Chamber door, to learn ome News of her; but he was not permitted to enter. That Novelty did urprie and diturb'd her. The Prince had the ame fate, and was tartled at an order that was not to concern him.

Finally the next day Contantia appear'd; but with o much Dejection, that it was difficult to believe that he had uffer'd much. Agnes was the mot preing to approach her. The Princes could not contain her Tears. They both kept ilence along time, Contantia did attribute that of Agnes, to ome remore, and that Unfortunate Maid not being able to contain any longer; is it poible, Madam, aid he, that two days can have depriv'd me of all that Bounty which you had for me? What have I done? And for what Crime are you thus to punih me? The Princes look'd languihingly
upon her, and did not anwer her, but with a igh, and Agnes offended at uch a reervednes, went out after an haty manner, which contributed much to make her be thought Guilty.

After this the Prince came, who found Contantia more diturb'd then uually, and he mot obligingly did Conjure her, not to neglect her Indipoition. My greatet good, is not the Preervation of my Life, My Lord, anwer'd he, I hould take more care of it, did I love you les; But — he could not go on, and the Prince being put into a Conternation through her diturbance, did mot orrowfully igh'd without anwering, which caus'd her an increae of Sorrow. To this ome grains of anger being added, and all things tending to perwade the Princes that he was Sacrificed amongt them, he did not enter on any dicoure that might produce
a right undertanding, o left her Husband retire without peaking to him.

Nothing is more capable of diturbing our Reaon, and of altering our Health, then the ecret Motions of Jealouy and Solitude. Contantia who was accutom'd, to pake freely to Agnes, and who beleiv'd he was deceiv'd by her, did Abandon her elf to uch Perplexity as quite did overcome her. She fell violently Sick. The whole Court was concern'd at this Misfortune; and Don Pedre was really Afflicted at it: But Agnes appear'd more Concern'd then all the Ret.

Contantia's Coldnes towards her, her continual ighs, and her obtinate Ditemper, caus'd that after he had ought after the occaion of it, in all that he could recal into her Memory, he began to fear her elf, and to reproach her elf for all that the Princes did uffer.

Mean time the Ditemper did o increae that Contantia's Life was extreamly fear'd, and that he her elf began to find that it was time to think no longer of it; that though caus'd her no diturbance, She look'd on Death as a great good, and perceiv'd the depair thoe Perons approach'd her were in without the leat Concern.

Don Alfone who lov'd her and knew her Virtue, was mov'd at the Extremity he was in, and Don Alvare's who had not lot the leat occaion, of making him conceive that it was Jealouy which caus'd Contantia's Death, did but too much Exaperate him againt uch Criminals as were mot worthy of Compaion.

The King of Portugal was not of a Temper long to Conceal his Anger. You give Examples, aid he to the Prince, that will render your Memory very Illutrious, and Contantia's Death, of which none
but you can be accus'd, is the Unfortunate Effects of a Guilty Paion. Dread Heaven after this, and look on your elf as a Monter that deerves not to Live. If my Blood did not till Plead in your behalf, what might you not fear from my jut Reentments? But what may not the Imprudent Agnes, to whom nothing Binds me, expect, if Contantia Perihes? She that in my Court Foments your foolih Paion with vain hopes, and caues us to looe o Amiable a Princes, that you were not worthy to poes.

Don Pedre knew, that Contantia was not Ignorant of his concerns for Agnes; but he alo knew with what Moderation he had always expres'd her elf on that point. The Kings reproach was very enible; but his fault not being voluntary, and that an Imperious Accident did force him to Love in depight of
all his reitance, he appear'd more Afflicted, then Confounded. Without well examining of me, you have accus'd me, Sir, anwer'd he, and if my intentions were well known to you, you would not, may be, find me o guilty, I hould take the Princes whom you ay I Sacrifice for Judge of my Actions, were he in a Condition to be Conulted. If I am Guilty of any Weaknes, her Equity has never reproach'd me of it, and my Mouth has never informed Agnes of it. But Sir, though I had Committed ome Fault wherefore would you Punih an Innocent Maid for it? Who would perhaps Condemn them as much as you do? Ah! Wretch reply'd the King, he has but too much favour'd you, and thy flames had not been o contant had they not been well rewarded. Sir, reply'd the Prince, peirc'd with Sorrow for the wrong which was offer'd to Agnes, you
offend a Virtue mot pure, and thoe expreions which proceed from your Anger, do not become you. Agnes has afforded me no Favours, I did never ask her any, and I protet that I have not had o much as a thought againt what I owe to Contantia.

While they were in this Dicoure one of the Princees Women came all in Tears to Advertie Don Pedre, that he was at the lat Gape. Go look on your Work, aid the King, and expect no longer, from a Father, who has but too much par'd you, but that Severity which you deerve.

The Prince did run to Contantia, who he found Dying, and Agnes in a Swound in the Arms of ome Women. That which had caus'd that redoubling of illnes, was that Agnes, who could no longer bear the Princes indifferency, had Conjur'd her to tell
her what her Crime was, and either to deprive her of life or retore her Friendhip to her.

Contantia who felt that he mut uddainly Dye, would not retain a ecred Anger againt Agnes, and after ome words that prepar'd her to a orrowful clearing of the buines he hew'd her that Pernicious Note, which Elvira had Compos'd. Ah! Madam, cry'd out the Beautiful Agnes, after he had Read it, Ah! Madam, how many orrowful diquiets had you pared me, if your Heart had expres'd it elf with its accutomed Bounty. It is not hard to ee that this Letter is Artificial, and that I have mot Merciles Enemies. Can you believe the Prince o Imprudent as to employ another Hand, then his own in uch an occaion as this? And do you think me o imple as to keep that tetimony of my hame with o little Cautiounes? you are not betray'd, neither
by your Husband, nor by me I call Heaven to Witnes, and thoe Attempts which I made to get out of Coimbria. Alas! My Dear Princes, how little have you known he that you have o Honour'd. Believe not that if I have jutify'd my elf, I hall ever uffer the Worlds Converation. No, no, there is no retreat ditant enough for me to flye to, and I hall o well conceal my face, that it hall never give offence.

The Princes mov'd at Agnes dicoure and Tears, did pres her hand, which he held, and fixing her looks on her, capable to move compaion in the mot inenible Souls; If I have done you any wrong, my dear Agnes, anwer'd he, Death which I expect every moment will avenge you of it. I ought alo to protet to you, that I have not ceaed loving you, and that I believe all that you ay, in giving you again my mot tender affection.

It was then that that orrow, which acted on them both did reduce them to that extremity, which caus'd the Prince to be call'd in. He was incapable of doing any thing at the fight of them, and notwithtanding thoe tender motions that inclin'd him towards Agnes, he run directly to Contantia.

The Princes, unto whom a cold clammy weat did denounce her lat moment, felt that he had no time to looe and cauing all Perons to withdraw that he upected, my Lord, aid he to Don Pedre. Though I quit my life without repining, I leave not you without regret and trouble. But dear Prince I mut overcome even dying, and I will wholly forget my elf, to turn my thoughts only on you. I reproach you not, well knowing that it is inclination alone that dipoes of Hearts, and not reaon. Agnes is ufficiently Beautiful, to inpire mot ardent paions,
and ufficiently virtuous to deerve the bet Fortune in the World. I alo ask her Pardon for ome mall wrong which I have done her, and recommend her to you, as a Peron mot dear to me. Promie me, before I expire, to give her my Place in your dominions. It cannot be better fill'd. You cannot make choice of a more perfect Princes for your People, nor a better Mother for your Children. And you my dear and faithful Agnes, continu'd he, lend not an ear to a too crulous virtue, which might oppoe it elf to the Prince of Portugals happines. Refue him not, an Heart that he is worthy of, and give him that Friendhip which you had for me, with that which you owe to his Merit. Take care of young Ferdinando, and of the two little Princees that will retrieve me in you, pake of me ometimes to them. Farewell
live both happy, and receive my lat embraces.

The afflicted Agnes, who had recover'd a little of trength, lot once more all her enes. Her faintnes was follow'd with uch violent Convulions that her life was in very great danger. But Don Pedre kept cloe to Contantia, what, Madam, would you depart; and with a belief that it were an advantage to me. Ah! Contantia if my Heart has in any wie wrong'd you, your own virtue punihes it, againt your will for it. Think you me o barbarous —as he was going to continue he perceiv'd that Death was cloing for ever the generous Princes's Eyes, and it little wanted that he did not follow her.

But what an abys of Sorrow was this to Agnes? o oon as he learn'd, during a repite, that her reaon receiv'd that Contantia was newly expir'd, he would have
detroy'd her elf, and gave a full cope to her dipair.

At the Noie of this Death both the City and Fields were in an uproar, Elvira who then aw Don Pedre free to dipoe of himelf, repented for having contributed to the Death of the Princes. Don Pedre who accus'd himelf of it, did condole his Misfortune; And Agnes who thought herelf the true caue of it, did promie to her grief that he would never forgive herelf for it.

There was reaon to watch her for divere days, in which he dryed not her Tears The Prince imploy'd them in a deep Mourning; But when the firt Notions of grief were over, thoe of his love made him enible that he was till the ame.

Don Alvares, who fear'd now the Prince's diengagement, made new attempts to gain Agnes de Catro, who was become inenible of
all things but of her own dicontent. Elvira deirous to reap advantage from her own dexterity, imploy'd all the Art, and Craft in her brains, to rekindle thoe fires wherewith the Prince had formerly courted her; but his incontancy was already limited, and Agnes alone was to reign over his Heart.

She had taken a firm reolution ince the Death of Contantia to give her elf wholly up to retirednes for the ret of her Life. Maugre all the Cautiounes which he us'd to conceal her deign, the Prince was inform'd of it, endeavour'd all he could to dipoe his contancy to ubmit to it. He beleiv'd himelf tronger then he was in that point; but after he had well Conulted himelf, he knew but too well, how much Agnes's preence was neceary to his welfare. Madam, aid he to her one day, his Heart ready to break,
and his Eyes full of Tears, which of the Actions of my Life, may have caus'd you to reolve on my Death! Though I have never told you how much I Love you, I am Perwaded that you are not Ignorant of it. I have been forc'd to ilence during many years, for yours, Contantia's, and my own ake; But it is no longer in my power o to contrain my elf, and I ought to expres my elf at leat once with you. Receive therefore the aurance of a paion, full of repect and of heat with the offer of my Fortune, which I hould not wih better, but to hare it with you.

Agnes anwer'd not at firt to thee words but with abundance of Tears; at lat having dryed them up, and looking on Don Pedre with an Air, which gave him to undertand that he was not well agreed with her wihes; If I were capable of that Weaknes
which you would inpire me with, My Lord, reply'd he, you were oblig'd to Punih me for it. What, Contantia is carce in her Tomb, and you would have me to offend her thus? No my Dear Princes, added he, with more vehemency, No, he who you have o much weighed down with favours, hall not deerve the cure of Heavens and the corn of Men by o perfidious an action. Do not therefore, my Lord, • btinate your elf in a deign which I hall never approve of. You owe Constantia ever after her Death, uch a fidelity as may jutifie you; and I, to repair thoe Afflictions which I have caus'd her, I ought to avoid all Converation with you. Go Madam, reply'd the Prince, changing Colour, go and expect the News of my Death, in thoe places where your Cruelty hall Conduct you. They hall follow you cloe, and that War,
that now employs our Neighbours will oon procure it me.

Thoe words made the Beauteous Agnes of Catro to feel that her innocence was not altogether uch as he had taken it to be, and that her Heart did concern it elf for the Prince. You owe the Preervation of your Life unto the Prince and Princes, that Contantia has left you, he tenderly reply'd. Would you abandon their Youth to Don Alvares? Live, my Lord, live, and Permit the mot unhappy Agnes to fall a ingle Sacrifice? Ah! thou Cruel Maid, reply'd the Prince, why do you order me to Live, if I cannot live without you? Is it an effect of your hatred? No, My Lord, reply'd Agnes, with ome concern, I hate you not; and would to Heaven that a little of indifferency would come and ait my Weaknes, caue me not to ay more. You perceive my Bluhes, expound them as you
pleae; but till conider, that the les Averion I find in me towards you, the more guilty I render my elf, and that I ought not to ee or pake to you. In fine, My Lord, if you oppoe my retirement, I declare that Don Alvares, as odious to me as he is, hall erve me as a fence againt you, and that I hall rather reolve to marry a Man which I abhore, than to favor a paion which has caus'd Contantia's Life. Well, Agnes, reply'd the Prince with looks full of orrow, follow thoe Motions that your Barbarous Virtue inpires you with. Take thoe cautious Meaures which you judg mot neceary, againt an Unfortunate Love, and enjoy the Glory of having refus'd all to my deires.
He retired at thee words, and all troubled, as was Agnes, he would not retain him; Her Courage overcame her Grief and he thought more then ever on her depart.

It had been difficult for her to leave Coimbria, without the Kings conent, and not to defer that which appear'd o neceary to her, he was at Don Alfones Apartment. Maugre Don Alvares interets, he hew'd her a evere brow, and yet not being able to give his conent to her requet, you hall not tir from hence, aid he, and if you are wie, you will here hare and enjoy any Friendhip with Don Alvares. I have deign'd another way, Sir, anwer'd Agnes, and the World has no hare in it. You might except Don Pedre, reply'd the King of Portugal, his condition may atisfy an ambitious Peron; but you would not ucceed Contantia, who o tenderly lov'd you; and Spain hath more Princees wherewith to fill, a part of that Throne, which I am to leave to my Son, Sir, reply'd Agnes, touch'd to the quick with that dicoure. If I had any dipoitions for Love,
and deigns of mariage, the Prince hould be perhaps the only Peron, on whom I could fix them, and you, Sir, know that if my ancetors wore no crowns yet they were not unworthy of them. However I will be gone, and I believe not my elf a Slave in a place in which I came free.

This bold Anwer, which dicover'd truly Agne's Character, did tartle Don Alfone, and at the ame time did vex him alo. You hall go, when we hall think it convenient, reply'd he, and without being a Slave at Coimbria you hall however expect our orders there.

Agnes well aw that there was no hrinking from thence and he was o troubled at it, that he kept her Chamber for many days, without daring to inquire after the Prince; and that olitude av'd her the labour of eeing Don Alvares.

During this Don Pedre fell ick,
with o much violence and danger, that the fear of his Death was general. Agnes could not doubt but that it was an effect of his troubles he at firt believ'd her elf ufficiently trong to ee him dye, rather then prove favourable; but ome mall reflections did oon convince her of the contrary. She found not in the bottom of her Heart that cruel contancy, which he thought to be o firmly etablih'd there. She felt ome trouble and diorder, hed Tears, made wihes, and finally dicovered all her Weaknes.

None could behold the Heir to the Crown, and a Prince that o well deerv'd it in that extremity, without a general affliction. The People who lov'd him, did pas whole days at the Palace Gates, to learn news of his health, and the Courtiers were orrowful.

Don Alvares alone could conceal a Malicious Joy before the
King, under orrowful appearances. Elvira full of tendernes, and perhaps of remore uffer'd on her part alo. The King who though he condemn'd his Sons love, did however love him, could not reolve to looe him, and Agnes de Catro, who knew the exces of his grief expected the end with trange agitations.
Finally after more then a Month of fears, ome little hopes did appear. The Prince himelf, with Don Alvares, were the only two, that had no joy at it, but Agnes did feel enough for all the ret.

Don Pedre perceiving that he mut reolve to live, againt his own will, thought no longer then how to pas orrowful days, o oon as he was able to go, he ought after olitarines, and even gain'd o much over his weaknes, as to go in all Places where Agnes did not appear but her Idea follow'd
him till every where, and his memory very faithful in repreenting her to him with o many Charms, did till render her dangerous.

One day, that he had been conducted in the Garden, he ought after a Labyrinth which was at the farthet end, there to conceal his Melancholy during ome hours, he found the orrowful Agnes, who had been brought thither by thoughts little differing from his, and her ight which he expected not, caus'd him to tagger, he perceiv'd in his Palenes, and weaknes, ome relicks of his dieae. His Eyes full of Languihments, diturb'd her; and notwithtanding the deire he had to fly, an unknown Power retain'd her, and it was impoible for her to retreat.

After ome moments of ilence which was interrupted with many ighs, Don Pedre did rie from a
place where his weaknes had caus'd him to ret, he hew'd to Agnes coming towards her, orrowful marks of his ufferings, and not contented to conerne her pitty by her Eyes; you had reolv'd my Death, cruel Agnes, aid he, to her, my will was agreed to it; but the Heavens would reerve me for greater evils, and I again behold you, as unfortunate, but more in amour'd then I was before;

Agnes wanted not thoe words to molify her, the Prince's languidnes did pake, and that fair Maids Heart was but too well dipos'd to render up it elf. She then believ'd that Contantia ought to ret atisfied. Love who Combated for Don Pedre, did triumph over Friendhip, and found out that happy moment, after which the Prince of Portugal had o long ighed.

Reproach me not of that which has cot me more then you, my Lord, aid he, and accue not an Heart that is neither ungrateful nor barbarous. I mut ay that I love you; but when that is confes'd what do you require more?

Don Pedre who expected not o favourable a revolution, did feel a double atisfaction, and falling at Agnes's Feet; he told her more, with a ilence which his Paion had caus'd then all the mot Eloquent words could have expres'd.

After he had been enible of all his happines, he conferr'd with Agnes on what they had to fear from Don Alfone. They concluded that the unfortunate Paper which had diturb'd Contantia's lat days, could not proceed but from Elvira, and Don Alvares. The Prince who knew that the King was eeking already after new
alliances for him, and that would have his Favorite to Marry Agnes, did o tenderly conjure her, to prevent her perecutions, to conent to a ecret Marriage; that he agreed to it after a long debate, I hall do all that you pleae my Lord, aid he, though I have but very orrowful foreights. All my Blood freezes when I think on that Marriage, and Constantia's Image eems as if it would prevent it.

The amorous Prince did overcome thoe cruples, and parted from Agnes with a atisfaction, which oon recover'd all his trength. He after that did ee her, with the Pleaure of mitery in love, and at lat the day of their union was come. Don Gill, Bihop of Guarda, performed the ceremonies of their Marriage, in preence of divers witnees that were Faithful to Don Pedre who became poes'd of all Agnes's Charms.

She liv'd not quiet for being now the Prince of Portugals wife. Her Enemies who till Proecuted her did not leave her without diturbance; and the King who was offended at her reitance, did abolutely command her to Marry Don Alvares, with threats to force her will if he continu'd refractory.
The Prince did highly take her part, and that joyn'd to the refual which he made of Marrying a Princes of Arragon, gave upicions of the truth to the King his Father.

He had a econd, but too much intereted in the buines, not to unravel it. Don Alvares, and his Siter did act in it with uch cares, gave uch largnes, and made o many promies, that at lat they did dicover the ecret engagement betwixt Agnes and Don Pedre.

There little wanted but that the King at firt o highly tranported, had not broke forth in a cruel manner againt the fair Princes. Don Alvares, whoe love did change into a violent hatred, did top his firt fury in making him conceive that though the Marriage could be made void he hould not be ufficiently reveng'd, and he o well did Poion Alfones mind, that he made him conent to Agnes's Death.
The Barbarous Don Alvares offer'd his arm for that horrid execution, and his rage did ufficiently anwer for the certainty of the acrifice.
Don Alfone, who thought the honour of his Family to be concern'd by this alliance, and particularly his in his Son's proceedings, did give a full power unto that executioner who animated him.

It was not very eay to execute that deign though the Prince did
not ee Agnes but in ecret, all his cares were till watching for her good, and he had been above a Year her husband, when Don Alvares found the occaion which he had o long ought after.

The Prince did not take much Pleaure, nor but rarely did ditance himelf from Coimbria. One unfortunate day, and et a part by the Heavens, for o horrid an act, he made a match at Hunting, towards a tately Houe that the Kings of Portugal have near to the City.

Agnes lov'd all that could pleae him, but a ecret trouble did make her to fear that unfortunate journey. My Lord aid he to him, being alarm'd without knowing for what, I tremble eing you to day, as if it was the lat time in my life. Preerve your elf my dear Prince,
and though the exercie you are going about is not always dangerous, conider the leat of dangers and bring me back all that I confide in you.
Don Pedre who had never een her o Fair and o Charming, did divers times embrace her, and went out of the Palace with his retinue not to return thither again till the next day.

While he was going, the cruel Don Alvares was preparing himelf for that Bloody execution which he had reolv'd. He thought it of that importance as not to ingage himelf ingly, and made choice, to accompany him in it of Don Diego Lopes Pacheo, and Pedro Cuello, two uch monters as himelf, whoe cruelties had been aur'd him by his preents.

They tay'd till night, and the
Bautiful Agnes was in her firt lumber, which was the lat of her life, when thoe murtherers came to her bed ide. Nothing had oppos'd Don Alvares, who was all powerful, and who was introduced near Agnes, by the blacket of furies. She did awake and perceiv'd, drawing the Curtain, by the light of a Taper, left lighted, the dagger with which Don Alvare's hand was arm'd. He having not covered his face he eaily knew him, and forgetting her own danger to think of the Princes. Jut Heavens! aid he lifting up her Eyes, if you will avenge Contantia, ret contented with all my Blood, and pare Don Pedre's. The barbarous Villain who heard her, gave her not time to ay more, and having not had the Fortune to move Agnes's Heart, he receiv'd the horrid atisfaction of tabbling it through with a Dagger, His partners did
give her ome blows alo, and there needed not o many to put an end to her innocent life.

What a Spectacle, for thoe that approach'd her Bed the next Morning, and what news for the mot unfortunate Prince of Portugal. He preently return'd to Coimbria at the firt rumour of this adventure, and did behold that which had certainly cot him his life, if one could dye of grief. After he had a thouand times embrac'd the bloody Corpe of Agnes, and aid all that a jut depair could prompt him to peak, he run up and down the Palace like a ditracted Man, requiring the Murtherers of his wife from things that undertood him not. He at lat aw the King, and without oberving any repect, he gave a full cope to all his reentments, after he had long poken, he fell oppres'd with grief into a faintnes which lated all the ret of
the day. He was carried into his appartment, and Don Alfone believing that this evil would prove his cure, did not repent him of what he had done.

Don Alvares with the two others went out of Coimbria, and that abence dicover'd their guilt, of which the mot afflicted Prince did promie a uddain revenge unto fair Agnes's Ahes, being reolv'd to perue them to the very end of the World. He made a coniderable party of thoe that were affectionate to him, and after he had made havok of thoe Territories which are watered by the Duero, he puru'd that War unto the Death of Alfone, inceeantly mixing of Tears with the blood which he pilt in revenge of his dear Agnes's Murther.

Thus was the end of the unfortunate Amours of Don Pedre of Portugal, and of the beautiful Agnes de Catro, whoe memory the Prince did faithfully preerve on his Throne, on which he et by Birth-right after the Death of Don Alfone.
